<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-129] [collections] Flat3Map.equals() bug</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-129</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Flat3Map.equals() fails a simple test:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public void testEquals()&lt;/p&gt;
    {
        Flat3Map map = new Flat3Map();
        map.put(&quot;a&quot;, &quot;testA&quot;);
        map.put(&quot;b&quot;, &quot;testB&quot;);
        Flat3Map mapClone = new Flat3Map();
        mapClone.put(&quot;a&quot;, &quot;testB&quot;);
        mapClone.put(&quot;b&quot;, &quot;testA&quot;);
        
        assertFalse(&quot;Maps should not be equal&quot;, map.equals(mapClone));
    }

&lt;p&gt;The code of Flat3Map.equals() is:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   public boolean equals(Object obj) {&lt;br/&gt;
        if (obj == this) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return true;
        }&lt;br/&gt;
        if (delegateMap != null) {
            return delegateMap.equals(obj);
        }&lt;br/&gt;
        if (obj instanceof Map == false) {
            return false;
        }&lt;br/&gt;
        Map other = (Map) obj;&lt;br/&gt;
        if (size != other.size()) {            return false;        }&lt;br/&gt;
        if (size &amp;gt; 0) {&lt;br/&gt;
            Object otherValue = null;&lt;br/&gt;
            switch (size) {  // drop through&lt;br/&gt;
                case 3:&lt;br/&gt;
                    if (other.containsKey(key3) == false) {&lt;br/&gt;
                        otherValue = other.get(key3);&lt;br/&gt;
                        if (value3 == null ? otherValue != null :&lt;br/&gt;
!value3.equals(otherValue)) {
                            return false;
                        }&lt;br/&gt;
                    }&lt;br/&gt;
                case 2:&lt;br/&gt;
                    if (other.containsKey(key2) == false) {&lt;br/&gt;
                        otherValue = other.get(key2);&lt;br/&gt;
                        if (value2 == null ? otherValue != null :&lt;br/&gt;
!value2.equals(otherValue)) {                            return false;                        }&lt;br/&gt;
                    }&lt;br/&gt;
                case 1:&lt;br/&gt;
                    if (other.containsKey(key1) == false) {&lt;br/&gt;
                        otherValue = other.get(key1);&lt;br/&gt;
                        if (value1 == null ? otherValue != null :&lt;br/&gt;
!value1.equals(otherValue)) {
                            return false;
                        }&lt;br/&gt;
                    }&lt;br/&gt;
            }&lt;br/&gt;
        }&lt;br/&gt;
        return true;&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
while it should probably be:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
   public boolean equals(Object obj) {&lt;br/&gt;
        if (obj == this) {            return true;        }
&lt;p&gt;        if (delegateMap != null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return delegateMap.equals(obj);
        }
&lt;p&gt;        if (obj instanceof Map == false) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return false;
        }&lt;br/&gt;
        Map other = (Map) obj;&lt;br/&gt;
        if (size != other.size()) {            return false;        }
&lt;p&gt;        if (size &amp;gt; 0) {&lt;br/&gt;
            Object otherValue = null;&lt;br/&gt;
            switch (size) {  // drop through&lt;br/&gt;
                case 3:&lt;br/&gt;
                    if (other.containsKey(key3)) {&lt;br/&gt;
                        otherValue = other.get(key3);&lt;br/&gt;
                        if (value3 == null ? otherValue != null :&lt;br/&gt;
!value3.equals(otherValue)) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                            return false;
                        }&lt;br/&gt;
                    }&lt;br/&gt;
                case 2:&lt;br/&gt;
                    if (other.containsKey(key2)) {&lt;br/&gt;
                        otherValue = other.get(key2);&lt;br/&gt;
                        if (value2 == null ? otherValue != null :&lt;br/&gt;
!value2.equals(otherValue)) {                            return false;                        }
&lt;p&gt;                    }&lt;br/&gt;
                case 1:&lt;br/&gt;
                    if (other.containsKey(key1)) {&lt;br/&gt;
                        otherValue = other.get(key1);&lt;br/&gt;
                        if (value1 == null ? otherValue != null :&lt;br/&gt;
!value1.equals(otherValue)) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                            return false;
                        }
&lt;p&gt;                    }&lt;br/&gt;
            }&lt;br/&gt;
        }&lt;br/&gt;
        return true;&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;#8211;&lt;br/&gt;
Stanislaw Osinski&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.carrot-search.com&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.carrot-search.com&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-128] [collections] IteratorChain - if first iterator empty, doesn&apos;t care about next ones.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-128</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If first Iterator in IteratorChain is empty, and next ones contain some&lt;br/&gt;
elements, first call to hasNext() on IteratorChain returns false. It should&lt;br/&gt;
return true if there are elements in other Iterators.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341197">COLLECTIONS-128</key>
            <summary>[collections] IteratorChain - if first iterator empty, doesn&apos;t care about next ones.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="amorfis">Pawel Stawicki</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 10 Jan 2004 21:27:13 +0000</created>

                            <comment id="12405784" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 10 Jan 2004 22:35:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed in CVS already (duplicate report).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405785" author="droutsis@ebs.gr" created="Wed, 22 Sep 2004 18:04:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think this still applies. Witness following test code:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;List emptyList = new ArrayList();&lt;br/&gt;
List nonEmptyList = new ArrayList();&lt;br/&gt;
nonEmptyList.add(new Object());&lt;br/&gt;
IteratorChain it = new IteratorChain(new Iterator[]&lt;br/&gt;
  &lt;/p&gt;
{emptyList.iterator(), nonEmptyList.iterator()}
&lt;p&gt;);&lt;br/&gt;
System.out.println(&quot;Next? &quot; + it.hasNext()); // prints false&lt;br/&gt;
System.out.println(&quot;Next again? &quot; + it.hasNext()); // prints true&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Have tried this with both 3.0 and 3.1 releases.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405786" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Thu, 23 Sep 2004 05:20:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Tested against CVS and 3.0 and could not reproduce. Suggest you check your &lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-127] [collections] Strong reference not really cleared in TestReference*Map testcases</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-127</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;It seems TestReference*Map fail to remove completely the strong references in  &lt;br/&gt;
testPurgeValues because some optimization may be done for local variables by a  &lt;br/&gt;
JIT compiler. It may be seen with CVS head of the kaffe VM. I suggest to modify  &lt;br/&gt;
the testcases using the attached patch. It makes sure that no optimized local  &lt;br/&gt;
variables are still on the stack. The bug is present in the head of SVN tree &lt;br/&gt;
(2005-04-30). It is fully reproduceable on kaffe VM (2005-04-30) with JIT3/x86.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342217">COLLECTIONS-127</key>
            <summary>[collections] Strong reference not really cleared in TestReference*Map testcases</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="guilhem@kaffe.org">Guilhem Lavaux</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 1 May 2005 02:21:34 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:02 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:02 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12409254" author="guilhem@kaffe.org" created="Sun, 1 May 2005 02:26:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=14884)&lt;br/&gt;
Introduce an auxiliary function for building weak references&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you use an auxiliary function to build the weak references and the map you&lt;br/&gt;
make sure that no optimization of the stack is possible. At the exit of&lt;br/&gt;
buildRefMap you only have weak references on the stack.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12409255" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 8 May 2005 02:28:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch applied, thanks&lt;br/&gt;
SVN revision 169101&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                            <attachment id="12333496" name="ASF.LICENSE.NOT.GRANTED--ref-collection.patch" size="5314" author="guilhem@kaffe.org" created="Sun, 1 May 2005 02:26:15 +0000"/>
                    </attachments>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-126] [patch] JDK 1.4.1 compil error / TestHashMap.java  does not define makeEmptyMap() in org.apache.commons.collections.TestMap</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-126</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Environment:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Win32 W2kSp2 / cygwin&lt;br/&gt;
Win32 JDK 1.4.1&lt;br/&gt;
CVS ant&lt;br/&gt;
CVS jakarta-commons&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There is problem with compiling. See attached patch, which I AM NOT&lt;br/&gt;
SURE if it is correct solution. At least it builds without this error.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;jari&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;root@W2KPICASSO:/cygdrive/d/java/apache/cvs/jakarta-commons/collections$ ant.bat&lt;br/&gt;
Buildfile: build.xml&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;init:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;build-java:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;build-test:&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Compiling 62 source files to D:\java\apache\cvs\jakarta-&lt;br/&gt;
commons\collections\dist\classes&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; D:\java\apache\cvs\jakarta-&lt;br/&gt;
commons\collections\src\test\org\apache\commons\collections\TestHashMap.java:74:&lt;br/&gt;
 org.apache.commons.collections.TestHashMap should be declared abstract; it &lt;br/&gt;
does not define makeEmptyMap() in org.apache.commons.collections.TestMap&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; public class TestHashMap extends TestMap&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;        ^&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 1 error&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-124] [collections][PATCH] SetUniqueList breaks when swapping entries</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-124</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If you create a SetUniqueList with two entries a and b:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;a,b&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Then you do:&lt;br/&gt;
Object a = l.get(0);&lt;br/&gt;
l.set(0, b)&lt;br/&gt;
l.add(0, a);&lt;br/&gt;
You expect to have swapped the two entries. But you get&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;b&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Which seems to be wrong.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-123] [collections] StaticBucketMap#containsKey(final Object key) can return illegal value.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-123</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;org.apache.commons.collections.map.StaticBucketMap#containsKey(&quot;any string&quot;) &lt;br/&gt;
can return true by mistake when null key is containing in buckets.&lt;br/&gt;
I think containsKey(Object) method has to be modified like the following.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public boolean containsKey(final Object key) {&lt;br/&gt;
        int hash = getHash(key);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        synchronized (locks&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;hash&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;) {&lt;br/&gt;
            Node n = buckets&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;hash&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;            while (n != null) {&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;if (n.key == null || (n.key != null &amp;amp;&amp;amp; n.key.equals(key))) {&lt;br/&gt;
+                if ((n.key == null &amp;amp;&amp;amp; key == null) || (n.key != null &amp;amp;&amp;amp; &lt;br/&gt;
n.key.equals(key))) 
{
                    return true;
                }&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;                n = n.next;&lt;br/&gt;
            }&lt;br/&gt;
        }&lt;br/&gt;
        return false;&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Kazuya Ujihara&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342724">COLLECTIONS-123</key>
            <summary>[collections] StaticBucketMap#containsKey(final Object key) can return illegal value.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="ujihara@aurora.dti.ne.jp">Kazuya Ujihara</reporter>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-122] [collections] CircularFifoBuffer not really Serializable</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-122</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Create a CircularFifoBuffer of size N. Serialize and deserialize a couple of&lt;br/&gt;
times. When adding element N+1, an error occurs. (OutOfMemoryError in our&lt;br/&gt;
testing environment, ArrayIndexOutOfBounds when running the code snippet.)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The error can be reproduced by running the following code snippet in a scrapbook&lt;br/&gt;
page in WebSphere Studio 5.1.2 (default JRE) on Windows XP (The error occurs at&lt;br/&gt;
the third add operation):&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;org.apache.commons.collections.buffer.CircularFifoBuffer b = new&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.buffer.CircularFifoBuffer(2);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;b.add(&quot;a&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.io.ByteArrayOutputStream bos = new java.io.ByteArrayOutputStream();&lt;br/&gt;
new java.io.ObjectOutputStream(bos).writeObject(b);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;org.apache.commons.collections.buffer.CircularFifoBuffer b2 =&lt;br/&gt;
(org.apache.commons.collections.buffer.CircularFifoBuffer) new&lt;br/&gt;
java.io.ObjectInputStream(new&lt;br/&gt;
java.io.ByteArrayInputStream(bos.toByteArray())).readObject();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;b2.add(&quot;b&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;bos = new java.io.ByteArrayOutputStream();&lt;br/&gt;
new java.io.ObjectOutputStream(bos).writeObject(b2);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;b = (org.apache.commons.collections.buffer.CircularFifoBuffer) new&lt;br/&gt;
java.io.ObjectInputStream(new&lt;br/&gt;
java.io.ByteArrayInputStream(bos.toByteArray())).readObject();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;b.add(&quot;c&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;bos = new java.io.ByteArrayOutputStream();&lt;br/&gt;
new java.io.ObjectOutputStream(bos).writeObject(b);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;b2 = (org.apache.commons.collections.buffer.CircularFifoBuffer) new&lt;br/&gt;
java.io.ObjectInputStream(new&lt;br/&gt;
java.io.ByteArrayInputStream(bos.toByteArray())).readObject();&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Solaris&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Sun&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341754">COLLECTIONS-122</key>
            <summary>[collections] CircularFifoBuffer not really Serializable</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-120] BeanMap.toString() causes infinite loop on circular object graph</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-120</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This problem is similar to the one in &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;lang&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&apos;s ToStringBuilder.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Linux&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340667">COLLECTIONS-120</key>
            <summary>BeanMap.toString() causes infinite loop on circular object graph</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mhawthorne@alumni.pitt.edu">_matthewHawthorne</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 17 Apr 2003 04:46:47 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:02 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:02 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.1</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12404117" author="rwaldhoff@apache.org" created="Fri, 18 Apr 2003 07:28:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Any thoughts on what the proper behavior should be?  Output nothing for the&lt;br/&gt;
second reference?  Output something like what the default Object.toString does?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404118" author="mhawthorne@alumni.pitt.edu" created="Fri, 18 Apr 2003 20:38:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I definitely think that it should output something.  Maybe the default&lt;br/&gt;
Object.toString() content, along with an indicator that the object was already&lt;br/&gt;
printed out earlier in the process?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404119" author="mohankishore@yahoo.com" created="Sat, 19 Apr 2003 00:09:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=5891)&lt;br/&gt;
Proposed implementation - will it help?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404120" author="mohankishore@yahoo.com" created="Sat, 19 Apr 2003 00:12:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Have added a proposed implementation. It should help where the cyclic behavior &lt;br/&gt;
is due to the values (or keys) pointing to parent list/map. If the embeded &lt;br/&gt;
objects toString methods are implemented in a manner that causes cyclic loop, &lt;br/&gt;
imho, we cant do anything about it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;btw, my proposal is not specific to this class - might be moved to a more &lt;br/&gt;
generic class, and the list/map implementations can use the utility method.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404121" author="rwaldhoff@apache.org" created="Sat, 19 Apr 2003 06:00:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;My mistake.  I had assumed BeanMap defined some specific toString() method.  Why&lt;br/&gt;
don&apos;t we just drop down to bean.toString() or &quot;Map&amp;lt;&quot; + bean.toString() + &quot;&amp;gt;&quot; or&lt;br/&gt;
something like that?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404122" author="mohankishore@yahoo.com" created="Sat, 19 Apr 2003 06:15:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;BeanMap&amp;lt; bean.toString() &amp;gt; sounds good to me.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;JDK collection classes dont check for cyclic references either...&lt;br/&gt;
Ran a test program:&lt;br/&gt;
        Map m = new HashMap();&lt;br/&gt;
        m.put(&quot;1&quot;, &quot;One&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
        m.put(&quot;2&quot;, m);&lt;br/&gt;
        m.put(&quot;3&quot;, &quot;Three&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
        System.out.println(m);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Output:&lt;br/&gt;
Exception in thread &quot;main&quot; java.lang.StackOverflowError&lt;br/&gt;
        at java.util.AbstractMap.toString(AbstractMap.java:559)&lt;br/&gt;
        at java.lang.String.valueOf(String.java:2013)&lt;br/&gt;
        at java.lang.StringBuffer.append(StringBuffer.java:365)&lt;br/&gt;
        at java.util.AbstractMap.toString(AbstractMap.java:562)&lt;br/&gt;
        at java.lang.String.valueOf(String.java:2013)&lt;br/&gt;
        at java.lang.StringBuffer.append(StringBuffer.java:365)&lt;br/&gt;
        at java.util.AbstractMap.toString(AbstractMap.java:562)&lt;br/&gt;
        ...&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404123" author="rwaldhoff@apache.org" created="Sat, 19 Apr 2003 06:33:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;BeanMap&amp;lt; bean.toString() &amp;gt; it is.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-119] [collections] Misnamed method in FixedOrderComparator: getUnkownObjectBehavior</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-119</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The method is probably meant to be getUnknownObjectBehavior()&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;From the class:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;FixedOrderComparator {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    ...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    /** &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Gets the behavior for comparing unknown objects.&lt;br/&gt;
     */&lt;br/&gt;
    public int getUnkownObjectBehavior() 
{
        return unknownObjectBehavior;
    }&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;    ...&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340939">COLLECTIONS-119</key>

    </item>


<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-118] [collections] LRUMap.removeLRU(LinkEntry) is passed wrong link entry</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-118</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The following program attempts to add 3 entries (a,b,c) to an LRUMap with max &lt;br/&gt;
size two.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The contents of the LRUMap are always correct but when the LRUMap fills up it &lt;br/&gt;
removes entry &quot;a&quot; but passes entry &quot;b&quot; to the removeLRU method.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;run:&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;a&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;a, b&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Remove lru b&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;b, c&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import org.apache.commons.collections.map.LRUMap;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public class LRUMapTest {&lt;br/&gt;
    public static void main (String[] args) {&lt;br/&gt;
	LRUMap map = new LRUMap(2) {&lt;br/&gt;
		protected boolean removeLRU(LinkEntry entry) &lt;/p&gt;
{
		    System.out.println(&quot;Remove lru &quot;+entry.getKey());
		    return true;
		}
&lt;p&gt;	    };&lt;br/&gt;
	map.put(&quot;a&quot;,&quot;a&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
	System.out.println(map.keySet());&lt;br/&gt;
	map.put(&quot;b&quot;,&quot;b&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
	System.out.println(map.keySet());&lt;br/&gt;
	map.put(&quot;c&quot;,&quot;c&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
	System.out.println(map.keySet());&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341405">COLLECTIONS-118</key>
            <summary>[collections] LRUMap.removeLRU(LinkEntry) is passed wrong link entry</summary>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-116] [collections] Getting rid of some javadoc warn messages (3.2-dev)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-116</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Salut. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Just called javadoc to create the java documentation and wondered about&lt;br/&gt;
some warnings, though everything seemed to be at the right place:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Tag @link: can&apos;t find removeLRU(LinkEntry) in&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.map.LRUMap&lt;br/&gt;
Tag @link: can&apos;t find moveToMRU(LinkEntry) in&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.map.LRUMap&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;LinkEntry&quot; is a static class in AbstractLinkedMap, LRUMap derives from&lt;br/&gt;
AbstractLinkedMap. Why javadoc does not know about &quot;LinkEntry&quot; then, while&lt;br/&gt;
java itself does?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The solution comes from the javadoc-API:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;Nested classes must be specified as outer.inner, not simply inner, for all forms.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;(&lt;a href=&quot;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/tooldocs/solaris/javadoc.html#@see&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/tooldocs/solaris/javadoc.html#@see&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;That is the reason, why javadoc spews warnings, when &lt;/p&gt;
{@link
#removeLRU(LinkEntry)}
&lt;p&gt; is used. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The correct code will look like this then:&lt;/p&gt;

{@link #removeLRU(AbstractLinkedMap.LinkEntry)}

&lt;p&gt;Actually i have found this only in collections.map.LRUMap, its really a minor&lt;br/&gt;
thing. But even Eclipse gave me the &quot;wrong&quot; code...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the collections, we use them intensily here &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Ciao.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341769">COLLECTIONS-116</key>
            <summary>[collections] Getting rid of some javadoc warn messages (3.2-dev)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="public@ecopatz.de">Olaf Krische</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 4 Oct 2004 06:07:15 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:01 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:01 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.2</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.2</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12407691" author="public@ecopatz.de" created="Thu, 7 Oct 2004 03:41:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=12970)&lt;br/&gt;
replacing javadoc statements in two methods&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407692" author="public@ecopatz.de" created="Thu, 7 Oct 2004 05:02:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The next patch is related to the BooleanComparator class.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Some public methods in that class refer in their javadoc comments to the private&lt;br/&gt;
variable &apos;trueFirst&apos;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Since the default package access in the build.xml is set to &quot;protected&quot;, the&lt;br/&gt;
javadoc generator will not see this private variable and gives warnings. The&lt;br/&gt;
result is incomplete documentation (broken sentences...)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But hey, there is the public method #sortsTrueFirst, to which these methods can&lt;br/&gt;
refer to.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So, this simple beauty patch just rewrites the javadoc comments a bit.&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12407693" author="public@ecopatz.de" created="Thu, 7 Oct 2004 05:03:45 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=12972)&lt;br/&gt;

ReferenceMap.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Just added full qualified names to linked classes, if they havent been&lt;br/&gt;
explicitely imported from the source files.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

                            <comment id="12407701" author="public@ecopatz.de" created="Mon, 18 Oct 2004 05:13:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Salve.&lt;/p&gt;

&apos;private&apos; to see, if javadoc runs clean now. Just got some other warnings.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The first &quot;fix&quot; is for &apos;TreeBidiMap.java&apos; in &apos;collections/bidimap&apos;. I have&lt;br/&gt;
changed the parameter name from &apos;index&apos; to &apos;type&apos; in the javadoc code from three&lt;br/&gt;
methods, because the variable is named &apos;type&apos; there.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The second &quot;fix&quot; is for &apos;AbstractInputCheckedMapDecorator.java&apos;. Just removed&lt;br/&gt;
the javadoc tag &apos;@param value&apos; for the method &apos;isSetValueChecking&apos;, since this&lt;br/&gt;
method has no parameter at all. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The third &quot;fix&quot; is for &apos;TreeList.java&apos; in &apos;collections/list&apos;. But here it is a&lt;br/&gt;
bit ambigious. The comment for the field &apos;AVLNode current&apos; from the inner class&lt;br/&gt;
&apos;TreeListIterator&apos; mentions the method #getLastNodeReturned(). There is no such&lt;br/&gt;
method, thats why the javadoc warning raises. Will such a method ever be written&lt;br/&gt;
there to access &apos;current&apos;? For example, the &apos;LinkedListIterator&apos; in&lt;br/&gt;
&apos;AbstractLinkedList&apos; has such a method. I &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Okay, whatever, i dont see a note, that this method will come. So i just deleted&lt;br/&gt;
the comment about #getLastNodeReturned()&lt;/p&gt;

                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-115</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;A very useful hish performance map.  Sadly I cannot use it in my J2EE env&lt;br/&gt;
because it isn&apos;t seriabilable and hence cannot be a parameter in any remote calls.&lt;/p&gt;

something that was overlooked?&lt;/p&gt;</description>

                            <comment id="12406352" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Thu, 1 Apr 2004 07:20:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Serialization is usually more complex than just adding &apos;implements &lt;br/&gt;
Serializable&apos;. In this case, a dedicated read/write was needed. Its done on CVS &lt;br/&gt;
now anyway &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

keys and values are all marked as transient.  Would this cause any problems when&lt;br/&gt;
reading the Map back from a serialized stream?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Cheers,&lt;br/&gt;
Manik&lt;/p&gt;

                            <comment id="12406354" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Fri, 2 Apr 2004 03:15:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There are dedicated readObject() and writeObject() methods, plus unit tests. &lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-114] [collections] Build Warnings when building under JDK 1.5</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-114</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When I build under JDK 1.5 on MacOSX, I get a bunch of warnings.  Almost all of&lt;br/&gt;
them are a result of some APIs moving over to using varargs.  Here is an example&lt;br/&gt;
of some of the warnings.  The fixes in just about all cases was to cast a null&lt;br/&gt;
to either (Method[]) or (Object[]).  in one place a temporary array new String[]&lt;/p&gt;
{ ... } had to be changed to new Object[] { ... }

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Compiling 271 source files to&lt;br/&gt;
/Users/willpugh/projects/beanutils2/collections2/collections/target/classes&lt;br/&gt;
/Users/willpugh/projects/beanutils2/collections2/collections/src/java/org/apache/commons/collections/functors/PrototypeFactory.java:62:&lt;br/&gt;
warning: non-varargs call of varargs method with inexact argument type for last&lt;br/&gt;
parameter;&lt;br/&gt;
cast to java.lang.Class for a varargs call&lt;br/&gt;
cast to java.lang.Class[] for a non-varargs call and to suppress this warning&lt;br/&gt;
            Method method = prototype.getClass().getMethod(&quot;clone&quot;, null);&lt;br/&gt;
                                                                    ^&lt;br/&gt;
/Users/willpugh/projects/beanutils2/collections2/collections/src/java/org/apache/commons/collections/functors/PrototypeFactory.java:119:&lt;br/&gt;
warning: non-varargs call of varargs method with inexact argument type for last&lt;br/&gt;
parameter;&lt;br/&gt;
cast to java.lang.Class for a varargs call&lt;br/&gt;
cast to java.lang.Class[] for a non-varargs call and to suppress this warning&lt;br/&gt;
                iCloneMethod = iPrototype.getClass().getMethod(&quot;clone&quot;, null);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;. . .&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-111] IteratorChain skips over elements in iterator</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-111</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hi there,&lt;br/&gt;
When using the IteratorChain class to add multiple iterators, it appears that&lt;br/&gt;
using itChain.hasNext() and itChain.next() skips a number of elements in the&lt;br/&gt;
iterator at each step.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Given a single iterator of 7 elements, and using the following code:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;private IteratorChain buildIterator() {&lt;br/&gt;
// this iterator contains the children of the current object only&lt;br/&gt;
Iterator it = getChildren(p);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;// we use an IteratorChain to add multiple iterators together without the&lt;br/&gt;
overhead of copying&lt;br/&gt;
IteratorChain itChain = new IteratorChain(it);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;return itChain;&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;and then simply&lt;br/&gt;
IteratorChain it = treeModel.getAllTreeNodes(obj);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;// FIXME this only prints one or two of the results, which is a bug!&lt;br/&gt;
while (it.hasNext())&lt;br/&gt;
    System.out.println(&quot;: &quot; + it.next().getClass());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I put in 7 elements, but only get 2 out - the 2nd and the last elements. It&lt;br/&gt;
appears that through my debugging that the nextClause variable is updated even&lt;br/&gt;
when the hasNext() function is called.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also, if I put 7 system.out.println statements, all elements are printed as normal.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342870">COLLECTIONS-111</key>
            <summary>IteratorChain skips over elements in iterator</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="5">Cannot Reproduce</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jo@jogiles.co.nz">Jonathan Giles</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 21 Jan 2006 10:12:26 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 28 Feb 2013 19:52:31 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 19 Mar 2008 06:52:30 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.1</version>

                        <due></due>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12411314" author="jo@jogiles.co.nz" created="Sat, 21 Jan 2006 10:24:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;As an update, I have just downloaded and tried using Collections 2.1.1 - that&lt;br/&gt;
works as expected. I will investigate the differences and try to post a patch.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411315" author="jo@jogiles.co.nz" created="Sat, 21 Jan 2006 10:34:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;(In reply to comment #0)&lt;br/&gt;
Replacing the updateCurrentIterator() method from the 3.1 package with the one&lt;br/&gt;
from 2.1 fixes this bug. Can someone investigate whether this is possible and&lt;br/&gt;
let me know?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411316" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 21 Jan 2006 10:52:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Can you build a test case to demonstrate the problem? Thanks&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411317" author="jo@jogiles.co.nz" created="Sat, 21 Jan 2006 11:05:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;(In reply to comment #3)&lt;br/&gt;
Hi there - I have tried - and I can&apos;t reproduce it outside of my environment.&lt;br/&gt;
But as I say, I now have two snapshots in my system, and I replace the method in&lt;br/&gt;
3.1 with the one from 2.1, it works exactly as expected.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, doing so causes the current test cases to fail in two areas:&lt;br/&gt;
testFurstIteratorIsEmptyBug()&lt;br/&gt;
testEmptyChain()&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;My simple test case works under both 3.1 or 2.1.1 however. It is:&lt;br/&gt;
    public void testSize() {&lt;br/&gt;
    	// we know that the size is 6 elements, so lets ensure that is correct&lt;br/&gt;
    	Iterator iter = makeFullIterator();&lt;br/&gt;
    	int i = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
    	while (iter.hasNext()) &lt;/p&gt;
{
    		++i;
    		iter.next();
    	}

&lt;p&gt;    	assertEquals(6, i);&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411318" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Thu, 26 Jan 2006 09:37:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There have been changes to the method updateCurrentIterator() between these&lt;br/&gt;
versions that we need, so we can&apos;t just reverse the change. I&apos;d love to fix any&lt;br/&gt;
bug that can be identified cleanly. For now though I&apos;m placing this in NEEDINFO&lt;br/&gt;
awaiting a test case.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12422266" author="scolebourne" created="Wed, 19 Jul 2006 21:55:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Still awaiting a test case against 3.2&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12519861" author="bayard" created="Wed, 15 Aug 2007 05:30:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If it&apos;s a bug that couldn&apos;t be recreated outside a particular environment... I&apos;m suspicious that it&apos;s a threading issue.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12526533" author="bayard" created="Tue, 11 Sep 2007 17:35:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Here&apos;s the 2.1.1 to trunk diff for that method:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;     &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;protected&lt;/span&gt; void updateCurrentIterator() {
         &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (currentIterator == &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;) {
-            currentIterator = (Iterator) iteratorChain.get(0);
+            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (iteratorChain.isEmpty()) {
+                currentIterator = EmptyIterator.INSTANCE;
+            } &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;else&lt;/span&gt; {
+                currentIterator = (Iterator) iteratorChain.get(0);
+            }
             &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// set last used iterator here, in &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;case&lt;/span&gt; the user calls remove
&lt;/span&gt;             &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// before calling hasNext() or next() (although they shouldn&apos;t)
&lt;/span&gt;             lastUsedIterator = currentIterator;
-            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt;;
         }

-        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (currentIteratorIndex == (iteratorChain.size() - 1)) {
-            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt;;
-        }
-
-        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;while&lt;/span&gt; (currentIterator.hasNext() == &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;) {
-            ++currentIteratorIndex;
+        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;while&lt;/span&gt; (currentIterator.hasNext() == &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt; &amp;amp;&amp;amp; currentIteratorIndex &amp;lt; iteratorChain.size() - 1) {
+            currentIteratorIndex++;
             currentIterator = (Iterator) iteratorChain.get(currentIteratorIndex);
-
-            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (currentIteratorIndex == (iteratorChain.size() - 1)) {
-                &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt;;
-            }
         }
     }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12526540" author="bayard" created="Tue, 11 Sep 2007 17:56:45 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The first block of code is a bit of protection that stops an IndexOutOfBoundsException. It&apos;s not possible to enter updateIteratorChain() without lockChain() having been called, so it&apos;s not possible for the iterator to be empty and then get values later. This initial bit of code looks good.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Then a return statement is removed. With the return statement, an empty iterator would be considered to be full, so removing this return statement makes sense. It does mean that there&apos;s a new code path to go through the first time. Jonathan does report that the first element doesn&apos;t return, which might point to this return statement; but he also reports other later elements are missing which doesn&apos;t. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The following changes are one change. An if statement is rolled into the while loop below it. It&apos;s the biggest change, but it seems to be fine. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The new code path means that:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;a) An empty iterator is passed down to the while loop. Its hasNext() is false and currentIteratorIndex (=0) is not less than size-1 (=-1). So the while loop is not entered and the method returns as before.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;b) The first iterator in the array is at its beginning. In Jonthan&apos;s case its hasNext is true, and currentIteratorIndex (=0) is not less than size-1 (0). The while loop is not entered and the method returns as before. The alternative to Jonathan&apos;s case would be an empty iterator, but that would also not enter the while loop due to the second clause.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So none of the code changes would appear to cause any problems, and things would appear to be thread safe because they are read-only at that time - unless more than one thing is reading the iterator.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;That&apos;s the only explanation I can see - that there was another thread that was sometimes reading the other iterator. It doesn&apos;t match to Jonathan&apos;s report of 2.1.1 being fine and 3.1 being bad.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve been looking at trunk and not 3.1. Looking at the diff between 3.1 and trunk, the only change has been protection in remove() against calling updateCurrentIterator() unless the currentIterator is null. As the report only has the one iterator in the chain, I can&apos;t see this bug leading to elements vanishing. updateIteratorChain doesn&apos;t do element moving, just iterators.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So... I&apos;m all for closing this as Cannot Reproduce. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12580253" author="bayard" created="Wed, 19 Mar 2008 06:52:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;As per my previous investigation, closing this as Cannot Reproduce.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-109] Bug in CollectionUtils</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-109</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;there is a bug in CollectionUtils. If you pass in a Collection object which is &lt;br/&gt;
not an instance of List to the CollectionUtils.index() methods, the method &lt;br/&gt;
doesn&apos;t work: it just returns the given Collection instead of the i-th value in &lt;br/&gt;
the Collection.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve already reported this (including a patch) to the commons-dev mailinglist, &lt;br/&gt;
but there was no reaction, that&apos;s why I&apos;m trying it this way.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here is the patch (if possible, I will also add an attachment including this &lt;br/&gt;
patch)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;regards,&lt;br/&gt;
Maarten&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;cvs diff -u CollectionUtils.java &lt;br/&gt;
Index: CollectionUtils.java&lt;br/&gt;
===================================================================&lt;br/&gt;
RCS file: /home/cvspublic/jakarta-&lt;br/&gt;
commons/collections/src/java/org/apache/commons/collections/CollectionUtils.java&lt;br/&gt;
,v&lt;br/&gt;
retrieving revision 1.8&lt;br/&gt;
diff -u -r1.8 CollectionUtils.java&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;#8212; CollectionUtils.java	12 Jun 2002 03:59:15 -0000	1.8&lt;br/&gt;
+++ CollectionUtils.java	18 Jun 2002 12:23:34 -0000&lt;br/&gt;
@@ -500,6 +500,17 @@&lt;br/&gt;
                 }&lt;br/&gt;
             }&lt;br/&gt;
         }&lt;br/&gt;
+        else if(obj instanceof Collection) {&lt;br/&gt;
+            Iterator iterator = ((Collection)obj).iterator();&lt;br/&gt;
+            while(iterator.hasNext()) {&lt;br/&gt;
+                idx--;&lt;br/&gt;
+                if(idx == -1) &lt;/p&gt;
{
+                    return iterator.next();
+                }
&lt;p&gt; else &lt;/p&gt;
{
+                    iterator.next();
+                }
&lt;p&gt;+            }&lt;br/&gt;
+        }&lt;br/&gt;
         return obj;&lt;br/&gt;
     }&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340249">COLLECTIONS-109</key>
            <summary>Bug in CollectionUtils</summary>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-108] [collections] [RFE] RemoveElementTransformer</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-108</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;There is transformer remove a element from a Set (modifing the original ser). &lt;br/&gt;
If I write proper javadoc and test case, could it be included in commons&lt;br/&gt;
collections.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341612">COLLECTIONS-108</key>
            <summary>[collections] [RFE] RemoveElementTransformer</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="cote@computer.org">Guillaume Cot&#233;</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 5 Aug 2004 01:23:22 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:01 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:01 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12407152" author="cote@computer.org" created="Thu, 5 Aug 2004 01:24:22 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=12334)&lt;br/&gt;
The proposed transformer&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407153" author="cote@computer.org" created="Thu, 5 Aug 2004 01:25:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=12335)&lt;br/&gt;
the test case&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407154" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 17 Oct 2004 06:01:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for your submission.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The aim of the functor package in &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;collections&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; is to provide basic functors, &lt;br/&gt;
not application specific ones. Whilst I can understand that this transformer &lt;br/&gt;
manipulates collections objects, I don&apos;t believe that it is a truly basic &lt;br/&gt;
functor suitable for collections.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-107] [collections] AbstractMapBag.BagIterator.remove broken</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-107</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I can&apos;t get in to CVS to see if this is fixed, but there is a bug in &lt;br/&gt;
AbstractMapBag in 3.1: BagIterator.remove() does not properly remove the &lt;br/&gt;
last instance of a given item; the result is infinite looping.  Here is a &lt;br/&gt;
patch.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;-steve&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Steve Clark&lt;br/&gt;
ECOS Development Group&lt;br/&gt;
steve_clark@fws.gov&lt;br/&gt;
(970)226-9291&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;&amp;#8212; AbstractMapBag.java.orig    2005-07-14 11:14:33.708373173 -0600&lt;br/&gt;
+++ AbstractMapBag.java 2005-07-14 11:15:30.566623793 -0600&lt;br/&gt;
@@ -221,7 +221,7 @@&lt;br/&gt;
                 throw new IllegalStateException();&lt;br/&gt;
             }&lt;br/&gt;
             MutableInteger mut = (MutableInteger) current.getValue();&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;if (mut.value &amp;gt; 0) {&lt;br/&gt;
+            if (mut.value &amp;gt; 1) 
{
                 mut.value--;
                 parent.size--;
             }
&lt;p&gt; else {&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342373">COLLECTIONS-107</key>
            <summary>[collections] AbstractMapBag.BagIterator.remove broken</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-105] StaticBucketMap.remove(Object) incorrectly handles key comparison</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-105</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve found a bug in the StaticBucketMap class, the remove(Object)&lt;br/&gt;
method:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    /**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Implements 
{@link Map#remove(Object)}
&lt;p&gt;.&lt;br/&gt;
     */&lt;br/&gt;
    public Object remove( Object key )&lt;br/&gt;
    {&lt;br/&gt;
        int hash = getHash( key );&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;        synchronized( m_locks[ hash ] )&lt;br/&gt;
        {&lt;br/&gt;
            Node n = m_buckets[ hash ];&lt;br/&gt;
            Node prev = null;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;            while( n != null )&lt;br/&gt;
            {&lt;br/&gt;
HERE&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;   if( n.key == null || ( n.key != null &amp;amp;&amp;amp; n.key.equals(&lt;br/&gt;
key ) ) )  &amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&lt;br/&gt;
                {&lt;br/&gt;
                    // Remove this node from the linked list of nodes.&lt;br/&gt;
                    if( null == prev )&lt;/p&gt;
                    {
                        // This node was the head, set the next node to
be the new head.
                        m_buckets[ hash ] = n.next;
                    }
&lt;p&gt;                    else&lt;/p&gt;
                    {
                        // Set the next node of the previous node to be
the node after this one.
                        prev.next = n.next;
                    }
&lt;p&gt;                    m_locks&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;hash&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;.size--;&lt;br/&gt;
                    return n.value;&lt;br/&gt;
                }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;                prev = n;&lt;br/&gt;
                n = n.next;&lt;br/&gt;
            }&lt;br/&gt;
        }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        return null;&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The test is:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;                if( n.key == null || ( n.key != null &amp;amp;&amp;amp; n.key.equals(&lt;br/&gt;
key ) ) )&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;should be:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;                if( n.key == key || ( n.key != null &amp;amp;&amp;amp; n.key.equals( key&lt;br/&gt;
) ) )&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;which is how it works in get(Object), containsKey(Object) etc. and which&lt;br/&gt;
is correct. We have a match if the keys match using == OR if they are&lt;br/&gt;
equal according to equals().&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340558">COLLECTIONS-105</key>
            <summary>StaticBucketMap.remove(Object) incorrectly handles key comparison</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="leo.sutic@inspireinfrastructure.com">leo.sutic</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 18 Feb 2003 02:15:34 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:01 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:01 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.1</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12403662" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 23 Feb 2003 00:37:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed in CVS head, thanks&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">
                        <customfieldname>Attachment count</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>0.0</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        <customfield id="customfield_10010" key="com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:importid">
                        <customfieldname>Bugzilla Id</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>17139</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310220" key="com.atlassian.jira.ext.charting:firstresponsedate">
                        <customfieldname>Date of First Response</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-104] [collections] Only last element is removeable when CircularFifoBuffer is full</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-104</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If the circular fifo buffer is full and you remove an item, that is not the last&lt;br/&gt;
one, it breaks.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;code example:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import java.io.*;&lt;br/&gt;
import org.apache.commons.collections.buffer.*;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;class Stub {&lt;br/&gt;
    public static void main(String[] args) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        CircularFifoBuffer fifo = new CircularFifoBuffer(5);
        System.out.println(fifo);

        fifo.add(new String(&quot;1&quot;));
        System.out.println(fifo);

        fifo.add(new String(&quot;2&quot;));
        System.out.println(fifo);

        fifo.add(new String(&quot;3&quot;));
        System.out.println(fifo);

        fifo.add(new String(&quot;4&quot;));
        System.out.println(fifo);

        System.out.println(&quot;adding 5&quot;);
        fifo.add(new String(&quot;5&quot;));
        System.out.println(fifo);

        String six = new String(&quot;6&quot;);
        System.out.println(&quot;adding 6&quot;);
        fifo.add(six);
        System.out.println(fifo);

/* uncomment the following block to avoid problem
        System.out.println(&quot;fifo.isFull?:&quot;+fifo.isFull());
        System.out.println(&quot;removing 6&quot;);
        fifo.remove(new String(&quot;6&quot;));
        System.out.println(fifo);
*/

        System.out.println(&quot;fifo.isFull?:&quot;+fifo.isFull());

        System.out.println(&quot;removing 3&quot;);
        fifo.remove(new String(&quot;3&quot;));
        System.out.println(fifo);

        System.out.println(&quot;removing 4&quot;);
        fifo.remove(new String(&quot;4&quot;));
        System.out.println(fifo);

        System.out.println(&quot;clearing&quot;);
        fifo.clear();
        System.out.println(&quot;removing 4&quot;);
        fifo.remove(new String(&quot;4&quot;));
        System.out.println(fifo);

    }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;



&lt;p&gt;==============&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;output busted:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;[]&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1, 2&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1, 2, 3&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1, 2, 3, 4&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
adding 5&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1, 2, 3, 4, 5&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
adding 6&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2, 3, 4, 5, 6&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
fifo.isFull?:true&lt;br/&gt;
removing 3&lt;br/&gt;
Exception in thread &quot;main&quot; java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: -1&lt;br/&gt;
        at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.buffer.BoundedFifoBuffer$1.remove(BoundedFifoBuffer.java:347)&lt;br/&gt;
        at java.util.AbstractCollection.remove(AbstractCollection.java:255)&lt;br/&gt;
        at Stub.main(Stub.java:40)&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Linux&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341996">COLLECTIONS-104</key>
            <summary>[collections] Only last element is removeable when CircularFifoBuffer is full</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="amir@mathforum.org">Amir Tahvildaran</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 13 Jan 2005 03:30:28 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:01 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:01 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.1</version>
                                                        <due></due>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12408547" author="amir@mathforum.org" created="Thu, 13 Jan 2005 06:12:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It seems like I incorrectly stated the problem.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It turns out the error can happen when the buffer is not full also.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;My new theory is that you can only remove an item from a non-boundary position&lt;br/&gt;
if there has not been a shift (shift=adding N+1 items to a buffer of size N).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In these examples the buffer is not full when the remove(object) is called.&lt;br/&gt;
As you can see the size of the buffer remains the same (6) however in the second&lt;br/&gt;
example a 7th item is added which causes a shift.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;[]&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1, 2&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1, 2, 3&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1, 2, 3, 4&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
adding 5&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1, 2, 3, 4, 5&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
adding 6&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
removing&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2, 3, 4, 5, 6&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
fifo.isFull?:false&lt;br/&gt;
removing 4&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2, 3, 5, 6&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
removing 4&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2, 3, 5, 6&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;=======&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;[]&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1, 2&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1, 2, 3&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1, 2, 3, 4&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
adding 5&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1, 2, 3, 4, 5&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
adding 6&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
adding 7&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
removing&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;3, 4, 5, 6, 7&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
fifo.isFull?:false&lt;br/&gt;
removing 4&lt;br/&gt;
Exception in thread &quot;main&quot; java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: -1&lt;br/&gt;
        at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.buffer.BoundedFifoBuffer$1.remove(BoundedFifoBuffer.java:347)&lt;br/&gt;
        at java.util.AbstractCollection.remove(AbstractCollection.java:255)&lt;br/&gt;
        at Stub.main(Stub.java:51)&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Thanks,&lt;br/&gt;
Amir&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408548" author="phil@steitz.com" created="Fri, 14 Jan 2005 23:16:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thank you for reporting this.  Looks like the problem is in BoundedFifoBuffer. &lt;br/&gt;
IIUC how this field is supposed to be maintained, the end field is not being&lt;br/&gt;
updated correctly. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408549" author="phil@steitz.com" created="Sun, 16 Jan 2005 07:52:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The problem was in BoundedFifoBuffer&apos;s iterator.remove method.  The shift&lt;br/&gt;
operation was not correctly incrementing / decrementing array indexes.  Changes&lt;br/&gt;
have been committed to fix this. Should be fixed in the nightly build starting&lt;br/&gt;
1/15/05.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408550" author="gudnabrsam@yahoo.com" created="Thu, 9 Feb 2006 01:05:37 +0000"  >&lt;ul&gt;

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-103] SoftRefHashMap is all kinds of wonky</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-103</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Many methods in SoftRefHashMap do not conform the the java.util.Map &lt;br/&gt;
specification.  After you populate a SoftRefHashMap using its put or putAll &lt;br/&gt;
method, it transforms the values into SoftReferences.  The get() method &lt;br/&gt;
correctly re-translates the SoftReferences back into the actual object values, &lt;br/&gt;
unless they&apos;ve been garbage collected.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, the entrySet() collection view does NOT perform this reverse &lt;br/&gt;
translation; iterating over an entry set gives you Map.Entry with SoftReference &lt;br/&gt;
values.  Since the equals() and hashCode() methods rely on iterating over the &lt;br/&gt;
entry set, equals() and hashCode() are broken in SoftRefHashMap.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also, it&apos;s odd that after I put(key,value), containsValue(value) will return &lt;br/&gt;
true, yet I won&apos;t be able to find the value in the entry set.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also, invoking setValue() on a Map.Entry in the entrySet will correctly update &lt;br/&gt;
the map with a new value; however, the old value is not returned as per the Map &lt;br/&gt;
specification.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also, the values() and entrySet() collection views are not backed by the map; &lt;br/&gt;
alterations to the map are not reflected in any existing values() or entrySet() &lt;br/&gt;
collection views.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also, containsKey(Object) is wierd.  If I put(key,value), and the value is &lt;br/&gt;
subsequently garbage collected, containsValue(value) will return false, yet &lt;br/&gt;
containsKey(key) will still return true.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Creating a values() collection view creates hard references to the map&apos;s &lt;br/&gt;
values, essentially ruining the point of the class (so long as the values() &lt;br/&gt;
collection view exists, the map does not function as a memory-aware cache).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Finally, iterating over keySet() and entrySet() is wonky.  Mappings might have &lt;br/&gt;
been removed by the garbage collector, but the iterators will still return an &lt;br/&gt;
object for the mapping.  So keySet()&apos;s iterator will return keys for values &lt;br/&gt;
that aren&apos;t there anymore, and entrySet()&apos;s iterator will return Map.Entries &lt;br/&gt;
with keys that map to null instead of values.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340235">COLLECTIONS-103</key>
            <summary>SoftRefHashMap is all kinds of wonky</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="pjack@sfaf.org">Paul Jack</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 3 Jun 2002 13:12:09 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 14 Jul 2006 05:45:38 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 14 Jul 2006 05:33:30 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>1</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12402657" author="pjack@sfaf.org" created="Sat, 8 Jun 2002 06:49:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Actually the values() method doesn&apos;t work at all.  It always raises a &lt;br/&gt;
ClassCastException, because the underlying map&apos;s values() collection is &lt;br/&gt;
incorrectly cast to a Set.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12402658" author="pjack@sfaf.org" created="Tue, 13 Aug 2002 01:26:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Deprecated SoftRefHashMap in favor of new ReferenceMap.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
