<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-102] Bag interface violates Collection contract</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-102</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The following methods as defined by the Bag interface violate their &lt;br/&gt;
corresponding definitions in the Collection interface:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;add(Object), addAll(Collection)&lt;br/&gt;
  The Collection interface specifies that the add method should return true if &lt;br/&gt;
the collection changes as a result of the call.  Since a bag&apos;s size always &lt;br/&gt;
increases as a result of an add operation, Bag.add should always return true.  &lt;br/&gt;
The bag interface specifies that add(Object) will only return true if the &lt;br/&gt;
object was not already in the unique set.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;remove(Object)&lt;br/&gt;
  The Collection interface states that only one occurrence of a given object &lt;br/&gt;
should be removed as a result of this method.  The Bag interface specifies that &lt;br/&gt;
all occurrences will be removed.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;removeAll(Collection)&lt;br/&gt;
retainAll(Collection)&lt;br/&gt;
containsAll(Collection)&lt;br/&gt;
  The Collection specification does not respect cardinality for these methods; &lt;br/&gt;
the Bag interface does.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The add, addAll and remove methods can be fixed easily, and code relying on the &lt;br/&gt;
old behavior can be rewritten simply using existing Bag methods:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   boolean r = bag.add(obj)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;can be replaced with:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   boolean r = !bag.contains(obj);&lt;br/&gt;
   bag.add(obj)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   boolean r = bag.remove(obj)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;can be replaced with&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   boolean r = bag.remove(obj, bag.getCount(obj));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The existing bulk operations could be implemented with static utility methods &lt;br/&gt;
in CollectionUtils (or possibly BagUtils), which would allow a smooth migration &lt;br/&gt;
path for code that relies on the current bulk operation behavior.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340233">COLLECTIONS-102</key>
            <summary>Bag interface violates Collection contract</summary>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-101] [collections] CursorableLinkedList iteration broken with previous</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-101</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;With a CursorableLinkedList, if you perform a Next, Next, Previous on an&lt;br/&gt;
iterator/cursor, then remove the last object returned by index from the list,&lt;br/&gt;
you will leave the cursor in an invalid state.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You should at this point not be able to call remove/set on the iterator, but you&lt;br/&gt;
can.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342378">COLLECTIONS-101</key>
            <summary>[collections] CursorableLinkedList iteration broken with previous</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-100] [collections] IteratorChain bug with empty iterators.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-100</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Haven&apos;t tried this with nightly builds, but 2.1 collections have the follwoing&lt;br/&gt;
problem: when the first iterator in a chain is empty, first call to &quot;hasNext&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
returns false, on second and subsequent calls, &quot;true&quot; is returned again as it&lt;br/&gt;
should. Here is an example:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        List emptyList = new ArrayList();&lt;br/&gt;
        List nonEmptyList = new ArrayList();&lt;br/&gt;
        nonEmptyList.add(new Object());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        IteratorChain it = new IteratorChain(new Iterator[]&lt;/p&gt;
{emptyList.iterator(), nonEmptyList.iterator()}
&lt;p&gt;);&lt;br/&gt;
        System.out.println(&quot;Next? &quot; + it.hasNext()); // prints false&lt;br/&gt;
        System.out.println(&quot;Next again? &quot; + it.hasNext()); // prints true&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Cheers,&lt;br/&gt;
Andrus&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341134">COLLECTIONS-100</key>
            <summary>[collections] IteratorChain bug with empty iterators.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="4">Incomplete</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="andrus-jk@objectstyle.org">Andrus Adamchik</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 3 Dec 2003 13:11:35 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:01 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:01 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.1</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12405578" author="amamment" created="Fri, 5 Dec 2003 01:11:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;A test for this bug (below) in TestIteratorChain has been present since &lt;br/&gt;
version 1.3 of the testcase (currently on version 1.6).  It looks like to &lt;br/&gt;
checks the same condition you point out and it does pass in the current &lt;br/&gt;
build.  Please take a look and reopen the bug if there&apos;s a difference I&apos;ve &lt;br/&gt;
missed.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public void testFirstIteratorIsEmptyBug() &lt;/p&gt;
{
        List empty = new ArrayList();
        List notEmpty = new ArrayList();
        notEmpty.add(&quot;A&quot;);
        notEmpty.add(&quot;B&quot;);
        notEmpty.add(&quot;C&quot;);
        IteratorChain chain = new IteratorChain();
        chain.addIterator(empty.iterator());
        chain.addIterator(notEmpty.iterator());
        assertTrue(&quot;should have next&quot;,chain.hasNext());
        assertEquals(&quot;A&quot;,chain.next());
        assertTrue(&quot;should have next&quot;,chain.hasNext());
        assertEquals(&quot;B&quot;,chain.next());
        assertTrue(&quot;should have next&quot;,chain.hasNext());
        assertEquals(&quot;C&quot;,chain.next());
        assertTrue(&quot;should not have next&quot;,!chain.hasNext());
    }</comment>
                            <comment id="12405579" author="klavergne@comcast.net" created="Sat, 6 Dec 2003 01:48:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have found the same problem. I took the test that you submitted here and tried &lt;br/&gt;
it with commons-collections 2.1. It failed on the first line checking the &lt;br/&gt;
hasNext() on the empty iterator. Here are the results of the test:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There was 1 failure:&lt;br/&gt;
1) testFirstIteratorIsEmptyBug(org.apache.commons.collections.iterators.&lt;br/&gt;
TestIteratorChain) junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: should have next&lt;br/&gt;
    at org.apache.commons.collections.iterators.TestIteratorChain.&lt;br/&gt;
testFirstIteratorIsEmptyBug(TestIteratorChain.java:189)&lt;br/&gt;
    at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)&lt;br/&gt;
    at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.&lt;br/&gt;
java:39)&lt;br/&gt;
    at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.&lt;br/&gt;
invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)&lt;br/&gt;
FAILURES!!!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405580" author="amamment" created="Sat, 6 Dec 2003 02:06:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;True enough....  Sorry I wasn&apos;t clear enough when I closed the bug.  This bug &lt;br/&gt;
has been closed since 2.1 Collectiosn was released.  The current nightly &lt;br/&gt;
builds, leading up to the 3.0 release (when I&apos;m not sure) have resolved this &lt;br/&gt;
issue.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you look in the CVS repository, that test is not part of TestIteratorChain &lt;br/&gt;
as of the 2.1 release.  It has since been added (I cut and past the text from &lt;br/&gt;
that class).&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-98] [collections] BlockingBuffer Should Include Cause Exception When Throwing BufferUnderflowException</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-98</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The code for BlockingBuffer throws BufferUnderflowException when a&lt;br/&gt;
InterruptedException is thrown.  But, the original InterruptedException is not&lt;br/&gt;
included or wrapped by the new BufferUnderflowException.  This makes it&lt;br/&gt;
difficult to determine if the thread was truly interrupted.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I believe the commons project has support for wrapping exception (to support&lt;br/&gt;
older JVMs).  This would be very helpful to support.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For instance, line 141 of the 3.0 version of BlockingBuffer.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks!&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342074">COLLECTIONS-98</key>
            <summary>[collections] BlockingBuffer Should Include Cause Exception When Throwing BufferUnderflowException</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sethladd">Seth Ladd</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 23 Feb 2005 06:22:27 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:01 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:01 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.0</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-96] debug and verbose print in MapUtils only handles String keys</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-96</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In MapUtils, if the key is e.g., Integer, fails with a ClassCastException:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        for ( Iterator iter = map.entrySet().iterator(); iter.hasNext(); ) {&lt;br/&gt;
            Map.Entry entry = (Map.Entry) iter.next();&lt;br/&gt;
==&amp;gt;            String childKey = (String) entry.getKey();&lt;br/&gt;
            Object childValue = entry.getValue();&lt;br/&gt;
            if ( childValue instanceof Map ) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                verbosePrint( out, childKey, (Map) childValue );
            }

&lt;p&gt;Should not be cast to a String, just use Object, and it works.&lt;br/&gt;
Same thing goes for the less verbose sister method, debugPrint&lt;br/&gt;
Thanks,&lt;br/&gt;
Matt&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

                            <comment id="12407401" author="tirso.canela@altana.es" created="Wed, 1 Sep 2004 23:23:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=12593)&lt;br/&gt;
Test Case&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407402" author="tirso.canela@altana.es" created="Wed, 1 Sep 2004 23:24:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sorry, my english  is very bad.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;PROBLEM: I think Method MapUtils.transformedMap fails because method &lt;br/&gt;
TransformedMap.transformedMap fails too, because internally the constructor &lt;br/&gt;
TransformerMap takes the parameters but it doesn&#194;&#180;t perform anything with them.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;See Attachment Test Case:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I want to add 5 to each one of the members of  the Map:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) FIRST TEST: DOESN&#194;&#180;T WORKS (because internally the constructor TransformerMap &lt;br/&gt;
takes the parameters but it doesn&#194;&#180;t perform anything with them.)&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;2) SECOND TEST: IT WORKS, but i think that it is not a correct solution or i &lt;br/&gt;
don&#194;&#180;t understand the MapUtils.transformedMap philosophia.&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;3) One possible solution could be changing TrasformerMap constructor like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    protected TransformedMap(Map map, Transformer keyTransformer, Transformer &lt;br/&gt;
valueTransformer) {&lt;br/&gt;
        super(map);&lt;br/&gt;
        this.keyTransformer = keyTransformer;&lt;br/&gt;
        this.valueTransformer = valueTransformer;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        //New&lt;br/&gt;
        transformMap(map);&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;4) Another possible solution could be changing the method &lt;br/&gt;
TransformedMap.transformMap from protected to public.&lt;/p&gt;







</comment>
                            <comment id="12407403" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 17 Jul 2005 02:57:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The MapUtils method is functioning correctly. It is not supposed to transform&lt;br/&gt;
existing contents of the map. Instead, it supplies a new map that will transform&lt;br/&gt;
from then onwards. I have added comments to clarify.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have also added a new factory method to TransformedMap and&lt;br/&gt;
TransformedSortedMap - decorateTransform - that will create the new map and&lt;br/&gt;
transform any existing contents. You will want to use this new factory method.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;svn rv219347&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;BTW, your English is great! And a test case always helps.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-94] [collections] New feature: Extend ReferenceMap with IdentityMap functionality (WeakIdentityHashMap)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-94</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hello All,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I would like to ask your opinion on providing IdentityMap features to &lt;br/&gt;
ReferenceMap. (I am particularly interested in WeakIdentityHashMap)&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Object cache is often implemented using ReferenceMap (WeakHashMap). This class &lt;br/&gt;
delegates decision on when to de-cache an objects on&lt;br/&gt;
Java GC.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In many systems Java objects that represent database instances use database &lt;br/&gt;
identity: methods Object.equals(Object) and&lt;br/&gt;
Object.hashCode() are redefined to use database identity (identity defined in &lt;br/&gt;
terms of object table + object primary keys).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When traditional java.util.Map is used to implement database caches different &lt;br/&gt;
instances of the same database objects present a problem: instances override &lt;br/&gt;
each other. Class  java.util.IdentityHashMap (Apache Collections 3.0: &lt;br/&gt;
IdentityMap) can be used to solve this problem - this approach uses &lt;br/&gt;
System.identityHashCode() to obtain reference hashCode and Java comparison &lt;br/&gt;
operator to compare keys (and values).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;What I need is functionality of IdentityMap combined with WeakReference-based &lt;br/&gt;
keys.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Is it possible to extend ReferenceMap with an ability to use reference identity &lt;br/&gt;
instead of object identity? I can send you my prototype if you are interested &lt;br/&gt;
(it adds about ten lines of code to ReferenceMap).&lt;/p&gt;



&lt;p&gt;Here are some links to Sun&apos;s bug parade pages that describe similar feature &lt;br/&gt;
request for Java&apos;s java.util.WeakHashMap:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://developer.java.sun.com/developer/bugParade/bugs/4809420.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://developer.java.sun.com/developer/bugParade/bugs/4809420.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://developer.java.sun.com/developer/bugParade/bugs/4500542.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://developer.java.sun.com/developer/bugParade/bugs/4500542.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;P.S. There is a need for this feature in Apache DB-OJB project.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;All the Best,&lt;br/&gt;
Andy&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341226">COLLECTIONS-94</key>
            <summary>[collections] New feature: Extend ReferenceMap with IdentityMap functionality (WeakIdentityHashMap)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bugzillaspam@malakov.com">Andy Malakov</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 29 Jan 2004 06:22:59 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:01 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:01 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-93] [collections] When the AbstractHashedMap is serialized and deserialized the data array doubles its size</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-93</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In the method &quot;AbstractHashMap#doReadObject&quot;, the method call &quot;threshold =&lt;br/&gt;
calculateThreshold(data.length, loadFactor);&quot; is after the &quot;put(key, value);&quot;.&lt;br/&gt;
The &quot;put&quot; method uses the threshold to check the capacity of the data array.&lt;br/&gt;
In this checking, the threshold is zero, leading to a resize of the data array.&lt;br/&gt;
At each serialization/deserialization the size of the data array doubles.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342150">COLLECTIONS-93</key>
            <summary>[collections] When the AbstractHashedMap is serialized and deserialized the data array doubles its size</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-92] MultiHashMap.values() isn&apos;t backed by Map</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-92</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The values() collection of MultiHashMap isn&apos;t backed by the map; changes to the &lt;br/&gt;
map are not reflected in a values() collection, and changes to the values() &lt;br/&gt;
collection are not reflected in the map.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Though MultiHashMap deliberately violates the Map contract in other ways, there &lt;br/&gt;
seems to be no legimate reason for it to violate the values() contract; since &lt;br/&gt;
values() can be implemented according to contract, it probably should be.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340236">COLLECTIONS-92</key>
            <summary>MultiHashMap.values() isn&apos;t backed by Map</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="pjack@sfaf.org">Paul Jack</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 3 Jun 2002 15:30:43 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:01 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:01 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>

TestMap.testValuesRemovedFromValuesCollectionAreRemovedFromMap, but override &lt;br/&gt;
that in TestMultiHashMap to be a no-op for now.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;(At least there is a test in place now)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-91] [collections] CollectionWrapper should implement Serializable</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-91</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The CollectionWrapper inner class (part of CollectionUtils) should implement &lt;br/&gt;
Serializable.  This would allow the creation of serializable lists in the event &lt;br/&gt;
that the user needs this functionality.  Making this change would assume that &lt;br/&gt;
all the objects contained in the list were serializable (not a big deal IMO.)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I discovered this problem when using ListUtils.lazyList() method.  The &lt;br/&gt;
resulting list is not serializable and I need it to be.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341101">COLLECTIONS-91</key>
            <summary>[collections] CollectionWrapper should implement Serializable</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

in CollectionUtils.  However, the issue of serializability of the decorators &lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-88] [collection] Map filter with MapUtils.predicatedMap feature request</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-88</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hello,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I stumbled into the following problem:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A client submits an http request with prefixed parameters. Each prefix will &lt;br/&gt;
have it&apos;s own javabean to populate. So if there are two prefixes, then there &lt;br/&gt;
will be two different javabeans to populate from the request parameters.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I created a PrefixPredicate that only allows values with a specific prefix. I &lt;br/&gt;
then used this PrefixPredicate to copy the Map with the request parameters to &lt;br/&gt;
a predicated Map with:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Map predicatedMap = MapUtils.predicatedMap(dataMap,keyPredicate,null);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, since the request parameters contain parameters with other prefixes &lt;br/&gt;
as well, this returns an IllegalArgumentException.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It would be nice to be able to specify to the MapUtils.predicatedMap method to &lt;br/&gt;
ignore entries that do not comply to the predicate instead of to throw an &lt;br/&gt;
exception.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There are lots of possabilities to filter on a Collection, but a Map is not a &lt;br/&gt;
collection...&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342188">COLLECTIONS-88</key>
            <summary>[collection] Map filter with MapUtils.predicatedMap feature request</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

&lt;p&gt;Map reqParams;&lt;br/&gt;
CollectionUtils.filter(reqParams.keySet(), filterPredicate);&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;The deeper request in this call is covered by the proposal to add FilteredMap to&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;collections&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Closing this call as wontfix.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-86] LRUMap.get doesn&apos;t change usage status</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-86</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;LRUMap drops the least resently added item, not the least recently used one. The&lt;br/&gt;
following test fails in line 6 (and 7, if you comment out 6).&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;1: LRUMap map = new LRUMap( 2 );&lt;br/&gt;
2: map.put( &quot;2&quot;, &quot;zwei&quot; );&lt;br/&gt;
3: map.put( &quot;3&quot;, &quot;drei&quot; );&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;4: map.get( &quot;2&quot; ); // now, &quot;2&quot; should be least recently used&lt;br/&gt;
5: map.put( &quot;4&quot;, &quot;vier&quot; ); // this should drop &quot;3&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;6: assertEquals( &quot;zwei&quot;, map.get(&quot;2&quot;) );&lt;br/&gt;
7: assertEquals( null, map.get(&quot;3&quot;) );&lt;br/&gt;
8: assertEquals( &quot;vier&quot;, map.get(&quot;4&quot;) );&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

            <summary>LRUMap.get doesn&apos;t change usage status</summary>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-85] ReferenceMap clears bindings too early</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-85</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hello. This week I had to debug some small example program we are currently &lt;br/&gt;
working on and it really took me a long time to find the actual problem because &lt;br/&gt;
apprently there seems to be a bug in the implementation of ReferenceMap, which &lt;br/&gt;
was really very unexpected for me. To me this seems very critical because I &lt;br/&gt;
reckon that the ReferenceMap is in wide use. Hence I am describing my findings &lt;br/&gt;
in detail.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The code is AspectJ code, but I also provide the bytecode. The puspose of the &lt;br/&gt;
code is to detect the so-called &quot;lock order reversal pattern&quot;, a temporal event &lt;br/&gt;
pattern which gives indication of potentially unsafe locking. It tries to &lt;br/&gt;
detect patterns where a thread t1 tries to acquire locks in the order l1 l2 and &lt;br/&gt;
another thread t2 tries to do so in the order r2 r1.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When you compile the attached code with the AspectBench compiler (www.&lt;br/&gt;
aspectbench.org) and then execute &quot;java LORTest&quot;, depending on the map &lt;br/&gt;
implementation you choose, one of the following traces is produced:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&quot;log&quot;: your commons impl. (Reference identity map with weak key and values)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&quot;log_jre&quot;: the JRE impl. (hash map with weak keys, no identity map, but does&lt;br/&gt;
not matter since the keys are threads, which do not implement equals(...))&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;(Both logs are also in the tarball.)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In log_jre you see that the LOR is detected (at the bottom). That works as &lt;br/&gt;
follows: Whenever a lock is taken, the relationship (thread,lock) is put into a &lt;br/&gt;
first (weak) map (see logging points &quot;Xa&quot;). Also, for all such relations which &lt;br/&gt;
are contained already, we put a reference to a pair (thread,(lock1,lock2)) into &lt;br/&gt;
a second map (logging points &quot;Xb&quot;). This represents the information &quot;thread&quot; &lt;br/&gt;
took first &quot;lock1&quot; then &quot;lock2&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As &quot;log&quot; shows, the weak map by commons is looses all the sudden some bindings. &lt;br/&gt;
(Compare to log_jre.) This seems really buggy, since subsequent logging output &lt;br/&gt;
shows that the threads and locked resources still exist! &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For me this is fully deterministically reproducable. I am using Windows XP with &lt;br/&gt;
this JRE:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java version &quot;1.5.0_06&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.5.0_06-b05)&lt;br/&gt;
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.5.0_06-b05, mixed mode, sharing)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can compile the code (using the AspectBench compiler) with &quot;compile.bat&quot; or &lt;br/&gt;
you can just run it with &quot;run.bat&quot;, if you like.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342952">COLLECTIONS-85</key>
            <summary>ReferenceMap clears bindings too early</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

                            <comment id="12411551" author="eric@bodden.de" created="Sat, 4 Mar 2006 16:00:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=17835)&lt;br/&gt;
The test case.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The zip file contains the sources and the compiled classes along with two batch&lt;br/&gt;
files to recompile and run the files. Also the zip included two dumps, one with&lt;br/&gt;
the commons map and one with the JRE map.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411552" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 26 Mar 2006 03:20:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the report.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Unfortunately, it hasn&apos;t helper me understand the issue particularly. I can&lt;br/&gt;
reproduce the trace you supply (note that log_jre is missing from the zip).&lt;br/&gt;
However, this doesn&apos;t help me understand what is going on.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For a start, I can&apos;t even find the piece of code where the commons ReferenceMap&lt;br/&gt;
is being created. I can&apos;t see what sequence of operations is being called, etc.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is a general problem with aspects - they break so much of what programmers&lt;br/&gt;
expect from Java.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In fact, I believe that this is just a special example of not correctly&lt;br/&gt;
synchronizing the ReferenceMap implementation. For example, here is the javadoc&lt;br/&gt;
of the purge mathod:&lt;br/&gt;
    /**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Purges stale mappings from this map.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;p&amp;gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Note that this method is not synchronized!  Special&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;care must be taken if, for instance, you want stale&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;mappings to be removed on a periodic basis by some&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;background thread.&lt;br/&gt;
     */&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;And the javadoc from the top of the class:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;This implementation is not synchronized.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;You can use 
{@link java.util.Collections#synchronizedMap}
&lt;p&gt; to&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;provide synchronized access to a &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;ReferenceMap&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;



&lt;p&gt;Basically, ReferenceMap has no synchronization, and no thread handling. Its only&lt;br/&gt;
interaction with threads is via the standard JDK API on a ReferenceQueue.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411553" author="eric@bodden.de" created="Mon, 27 Mar 2006 19:17:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Ok, thanks for the hint. That could of course be an issue. I will try to verify &lt;br/&gt;
this. Sorry about the AspectJ code - but there&apos;s not much to do about it. I &lt;br/&gt;
will report back in a bit.&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12422268" author="scolebourne" created="Wed, 19 Jul 2006 21:59:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Awaiting feedback - I will close as unreproducible otherwise&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12426106" author="eric@bodden.de" created="Mon, 7 Aug 2006 02:43:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hello. This was indeed apparently due to a lack of synchronization. My apologies for not noticing that earlier and for the late reply.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-83] Implementation of List with an AVLTree (TreeList)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-83</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The existing Java List implementations are rather slow if it comes to big lists &lt;br/&gt;
and insertions and/or random access.  To mitigate that this List is based on an &lt;br/&gt;
AVL-Tree and uses offsets to locate objects.  The following benchmarks show the &lt;br/&gt;
performance compared to LinkedList and ArrayList.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;          add     insert    get&lt;br/&gt;
TreeList  300     501       110&lt;br/&gt;
ArrayList  70   20390        20&lt;br/&gt;
LinkedList 50  226636    279742&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;add - 100K times add( new Object() )&lt;br/&gt;
insert - 100k times add( random() * 100K, new Object() ) on a List with 100K &lt;br/&gt;
elements.&lt;br/&gt;
get - 100k times get( random() * 100k ) on a List with 200K elements.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;P.S.: I will try to attach the code as a zip.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341244">COLLECTIONS-83</key>
            <summary>Implementation of List with an AVLTree (TreeList)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-82] [collections] Map.debugPrint improvements</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-82</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;debugPrint and verbosePrint in MapUtils makes a cast of the key to a string &lt;br/&gt;
(instead of calling toString() on it) which makes it impossible to use for debug &lt;br/&gt;
printin maps with keys other than strings.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340786">COLLECTIONS-82</key>
            <summary>[collections] Map.debugPrint improvements</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="max@eos.dk">Max Rydahl Andersen</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 13 Jun 2003 18:07:48 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:00 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:36:00 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.1</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12404459" author="amamment" created="Sat, 14 Jun 2003 00:35:53 +0000"  >
&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m attaching three patches....&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) TestMapUtilsPatch - test case to capture the error condition -&lt;br/&gt;
   ClassCastException if the map key is anything but a string.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2) MapUtilsFixPatch - makes the following changes to MapUtils:&lt;br/&gt;
   A) Refactor common code from debupPrint and verbosePrint&lt;br/&gt;
   B) Remove the cast to String&lt;br/&gt;
   C) Rename &quot;key&quot; argument to debugPrint and verbosePrint as &quot;label&quot;.  &lt;br/&gt;
      Paramter comment is updated appropriately.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;3) MapUtilsBehaviourPatch - changes behaviour of debug print&lt;br/&gt;
   A) Previously, debug print showed class names for any object values in the &lt;br/&gt;
      map argument.  Any nested maps, however, although printed, were not &lt;br/&gt;
      similarly treated.  Now the &quot;debug&quot; nature of the call propagates to &lt;br/&gt;
      all nested maps - class names for values are always printed.  &lt;br/&gt;
   B) Debug print now also prints the class name of any nested map after the &lt;br/&gt;
      map itself has been expanded - again, this is in line with the behaviour&lt;br/&gt;
      of debug print with any other type of value within the outer map.   &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404460" author="amamment" created="Sat, 14 Jun 2003 00:36:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=6796)&lt;br/&gt;
TestMapUtilsPatch - captures ClassCastException reported&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404461" author="amamment" created="Sat, 14 Jun 2003 00:37:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=6797)&lt;br/&gt;
MapUtilsFixPatch - Fixes problem reported + refactoring internally&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404462" author="amamment" created="Sat, 14 Jun 2003 00:38:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=6798)&lt;br/&gt;
MapUtilsBehaviourPatch - Changes behaviour of debugPrint to be propagate debug satus&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404463" author="amamment" created="Sat, 14 Jun 2003 00:40:08 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Please note that only one of MapUtilsFixPatch or MapUtilsBehaviourPatch should &lt;br/&gt;
be applied.  The latter incorporates the former plus the additional changes to &lt;br/&gt;
the behaviour of debugPrint.  (Forgot to mention this in my earlier &lt;br/&gt;
comment.    &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404464" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Thu, 21 Aug 2003 04:08:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have applied the first two patches, but not the third. The third makes sense &lt;br/&gt;
(I think...) but as there is no test case I can&apos;t judge for sure. So, if you &lt;br/&gt;
want it committed, can you resubmit the last patch together with a testcase &lt;br/&gt;
against the latest CVS. Thanks&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404465" author="amamment" created="Sat, 23 Aug 2003 04:57:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The following attachment provides a patch of MapUtils which updates the &lt;br/&gt;
behaviour of debugPrint as before, but, this time, includes test cases to test &lt;br/&gt;
the expected output.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A short summary of changes:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) debugPrintIndent method was renamed printIndent - it is used both for debug &lt;br/&gt;
printing and verbose printing.  Likewise, debugIndent field was renamed &lt;br/&gt;
indentDepth.  Further, a field INDENT_STRING was added (to capture the actual &lt;br/&gt;
WS string used for indenting) - these are refactoring/clarification changes &lt;br/&gt;
which do not affect output at all. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2) The &quot;debug&quot; nature of a print is now propagated to internal maps.  &lt;br/&gt;
Previously, only the contents of the outermost map was printed in debug mode.  &lt;br/&gt;
Any contained maps were printed in verbose mode.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;3) The &quot;debug&quot; behaviour of a print was extended to maps - the classnames of &lt;br/&gt;
maps are now printed as part of the output (just like the classnames of map &lt;br/&gt;
contents are printed).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404466" author="amamment" created="Sat, 23 Aug 2003 04:58:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=7922)&lt;br/&gt;
New Patch including test case for debug mode printing&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404467" author="amamment" created="Sat, 23 Aug 2003 04:59:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Please note that the previous patch has been created as from the src &lt;br/&gt;
directory.  Application of the patch from that level will change both main and &lt;br/&gt;
test code to include the changes I propose.  &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404468" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 24 Aug 2003 16:50:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch applied with some changes and additional tests. You may want to check &lt;br/&gt;
that my changes are OK for you. Thanks.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404469" author="amamment" created="Tue, 26 Aug 2003 01:35:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I disagree with two things in the changes made to my patch, though a bunch of &lt;br/&gt;
the others are great!   I also have a question about one of your comments.... &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) Some maps are allowed to have null keys.  Since the label field, during &lt;br/&gt;
recursion, contains the key, the guard within verbosePrintInternal as &lt;br/&gt;
currently stated will not print out any entry associated with a null key.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2) I think that even when a nested map is present, the type of the map should &lt;br/&gt;
be printed out in debug mode.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;3) You note that, in dealing with nested maps, it would make sense to have a &lt;br/&gt;
stack.  I can see that - otherwise, there&apos;s the possibility of infinite &lt;br/&gt;
recursion.  Is it acceptable to add an internal stack, and then add &lt;br/&gt;
synchorization to the stack within utilities of this sort?  &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404470" author="amamment" created="Tue, 26 Aug 2003 01:37:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I will create and attach a patch for items 1 &amp;amp;  2 above, and would value input &lt;br/&gt;
on item 3.  &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404471" author="amamment" created="Tue, 26 Aug 2003 02:16:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=7940)&lt;br/&gt;
Update to Allow printing of &quot;null&quot; label, and to output map type of nested self&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404472" author="amamment" created="Tue, 26 Aug 2003 02:18:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The patch attached does the following:&lt;br/&gt;
1) If the label supplied to debugPrint or verbosePrint is &quot;null&quot;, then uses &lt;br/&gt;
the string &quot;null&quot; as the label.  &lt;br/&gt;
2) If the value associated with a key is a reference to the containing map, &lt;br/&gt;
then &quot;this MAP&quot; is printed when using verbosePrint, or &quot;this MAP &quot; and the &lt;br/&gt;
type of the map is printed when using debugPrint.&lt;br/&gt;
3) Tests to show the above.  &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404473" author="amamment" created="Tue, 26 Aug 2003 02:19:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Note: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For item 1 above - I essentially undid the changes that you had made to my &lt;br/&gt;
original patch as this was my intention to begin with.  Please let me know why &lt;br/&gt;
you felt it might be a problem to print &quot;null&quot; as the label if the label was &lt;br/&gt;
null?  I think I may be missing something?&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12404474" author="amamment" created="Tue, 26 Aug 2003 02:23:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I also just checked backwards in the revision history - printing of the label &lt;br/&gt;
(key) as &quot;null&quot; was the behaviour prior to my initial change proposals for &lt;br/&gt;
debugPrint and verbosePrint.  &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404475" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Tue, 26 Aug 2003 03:42:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The reason I made the label change was that it doesn&apos;t make sense to me that a &lt;br/&gt;
null label should print &apos;null =&apos; at the top level. null is generally used to &lt;br/&gt;
mean &apos;ignore this argument&apos;, hence I made null just not output the label.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You are correct however that it should print the label null when nested. So I &lt;br/&gt;
have fixed this.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have also updated the &apos;this Map&apos; message to be the same as AbstractMap uses.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;See what you think.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404476" author="amamment" created="Wed, 27 Aug 2003 01:47:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Great.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I like the &quot;standardization&quot; with the output of AbstractMap.  I also like how &lt;br/&gt;
you&apos;ve handled the label.  But I&apos;m still concerned at the handling of null &lt;br/&gt;
maps.  If both label and map are null, then the call to this function &lt;br/&gt;
essentially vanishes....  Whether or not the label is printed out on the first &lt;br/&gt;
call, should the fact that the map is null at least be recorded with &lt;br/&gt;
a &quot;null&quot;?  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I can provide a patch - one line change - if appropriate.  &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404477" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Wed, 27 Aug 2003 07:43:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Add a patch for what you believe is sensible, it always helps.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404478" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Mon, 1 Sep 2003 00:55:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Change made to output null if map is null and null label&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

&lt;p&gt;        at org.apache.tools.ant.Task.perform(Task.java:317)&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.tools.ant.Target.execute(Target.java:309)&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.tools.ant.Target.performTasks(Target.java:334)&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-80] [Patch] [Collections] ExtendedProperties.interpolate does not do recursive substitution</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-80</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;Patch&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;Collections&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; ExtendedProperties.interpolate does not do recursive&lt;br/&gt;
substitution in commons-collections-2.1, but it probably should, when used with&lt;br/&gt;
getString(...).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Example:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;firefish.home=/tmp/firefish&lt;br/&gt;
database.dir=${firefish.home}/samples/cfengine&lt;br/&gt;
database.file=${database.dir}/db.xml&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;extendedProps.getString(&quot;database.file&quot;)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I found out that this can be fixed with the patch below, which is simply a copy&lt;br/&gt;
and paste from the CVS of org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractConfiguration.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	/**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;interpolate key names to handle ${key} stuff&lt;br/&gt;
	 *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@param base string to interpolate&lt;br/&gt;
	 *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@return returns the key name with the ${key} substituted&lt;br/&gt;
	 */&lt;br/&gt;
	protected String interpolate(String base)&lt;br/&gt;
	// copied from org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractConfiguration
	{
		return (interpolateHelper(base, null));
	}&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;	/**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Recursive handler for multple levels of interpolation.&lt;br/&gt;
	 *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;When called the first time, priorVariables should be null.&lt;br/&gt;
	 *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@param base string with the ${key} variables&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@param priorVariables serves two purposes: to allow checking for&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;loops, and creating a meaningful exception message should a loop&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;occur.  It&apos;s 0&apos;th element will be set to the value of base from&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;the first call.  All subsequent interpolated variables are added&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;afterward.&lt;br/&gt;
	 *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@return the string with the interpolation taken care of&lt;br/&gt;
	 */&lt;br/&gt;
	protected String interpolateHelper(String base, List priorVariables)&lt;br/&gt;
	// copied from org.apache.commons.configuration.AbstractConfiguration&lt;br/&gt;
	{&lt;br/&gt;
		if (base == null)
		{
			return null;
		}&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;		// on the first call initialize priorVariables&lt;br/&gt;
		// and add base as the first element&lt;br/&gt;
		if (priorVariables == null)&lt;/p&gt;
		{
			priorVariables = new ArrayList();
			priorVariables.add(base);
		}

&lt;p&gt;		int begin = -1;&lt;br/&gt;
		int end = -1;&lt;br/&gt;
		int prec = 0 - END_TOKEN.length();&lt;br/&gt;
		String variable = null;&lt;br/&gt;
		StringBuffer result = new StringBuffer();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		// FIXME: we should probably allow the escaping of the start token&lt;br/&gt;
		while (((begin = base.indexOf(START_TOKEN, prec + END_TOKEN.length()))&lt;br/&gt;
			&amp;gt; -1)&lt;br/&gt;
			&amp;amp;&amp;amp; ((end = base.indexOf(END_TOKEN, begin)) &amp;gt; -1))&lt;br/&gt;
		{&lt;br/&gt;
			result.append(base.substring(prec + END_TOKEN.length(), begin));&lt;br/&gt;
			variable = base.substring(begin + START_TOKEN.length(), end);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;			// if we&apos;ve got a loop, create a useful exception message and throw&lt;br/&gt;
			if (priorVariables.contains(variable))&lt;br/&gt;
			{&lt;br/&gt;
				String initialBase = priorVariables.remove(0).toString();&lt;br/&gt;
				priorVariables.add(variable);&lt;br/&gt;
				StringBuffer priorVariableSb = new StringBuffer();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;				// create a nice trace of interpolated variables like so:&lt;br/&gt;
				// var1-&amp;gt;var2-&amp;gt;var3&lt;br/&gt;
				for (Iterator it = priorVariables.iterator(); it.hasNext()&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
				{&lt;br/&gt;
					priorVariableSb.append(it.next());&lt;br/&gt;
					if (it.hasNext())&lt;/p&gt;
					{
						priorVariableSb.append(&quot;-&amp;gt;&quot;);
					}
&lt;p&gt;				}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;				throw new IllegalStateException(&lt;br/&gt;
					&quot;infinite loop in property interpolation of &quot;&lt;br/&gt;
						+ initialBase&lt;br/&gt;
						+ &quot;: &quot;&lt;br/&gt;
						+ priorVariableSb.toString());&lt;br/&gt;
			}&lt;br/&gt;
			// otherwise, add this variable to the interpolation list.&lt;br/&gt;
			else&lt;/p&gt;
			{
				priorVariables.add(variable);
			}

&lt;p&gt;			//QUESTION: getProperty or getPropertyDirect&lt;br/&gt;
			Object value = getProperty(variable);&lt;br/&gt;
			if (value != null)&lt;br/&gt;
			{&lt;br/&gt;
				result.append(interpolateHelper(value.toString(),&lt;br/&gt;
					priorVariables));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;				// pop the interpolated variable off the stack&lt;br/&gt;
				// this maintains priorVariables correctness for&lt;br/&gt;
				// properties with multiple interpolations, e.g.&lt;br/&gt;
				// prop.name=${some.other.prop1}/blahblah/${some.other.prop2}&lt;br/&gt;
				priorVariables.remove(priorVariables.size() - 1);&lt;br/&gt;
			}&lt;br/&gt;
			else if (defaults != null &amp;amp;&amp;amp; defaults.getString(variable,&lt;br/&gt;
				null) != null)&lt;/p&gt;
			{
				result.append(defaults.getString(variable));
			}
&lt;p&gt;			else&lt;/p&gt;
			{
				//variable not defined - so put it back in the value
				result.append(START_TOKEN).append(variable).append(END_TOKEN);
			}
&lt;p&gt;			prec = end;&lt;br/&gt;
		}&lt;br/&gt;
		result.append(base.substring(prec + END_TOKEN.length(), base.length()));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		return result.toString();&lt;br/&gt;
	}&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341157">COLLECTIONS-80</key>

                    <description>&lt;p&gt;There is transformer received map and return a array containing the values of a&lt;br/&gt;
list of keys.  If I write proper javadoc and test case, could it be included in&lt;br/&gt;
commons collections.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;

        <key id="12341610">COLLECTIONS-79</key>
            <summary>[collections] [RFE] MapToArrayTransformer</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

                            <comment id="12407149" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 17 Oct 2004 06:00:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for your submission.&lt;/p&gt;
