<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-61] [collections] FilterIterator doesn&apos;t reset when properties are set</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-61</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Test case follows:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;pre&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    /**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Test that when the iterator is changed, the hasNext method&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;returns the correct response for the new iterator.&lt;br/&gt;
     */&lt;br/&gt;
    public void testSetIterator() 
{
        Iterator iter1 = Collections.singleton(new Object()).iterator();
        Iterator iter2 = Collections.EMPTY_LIST.iterator();
        
        FilterIterator filterIterator = new FilterIterator(iter1);
        filterIterator.setPredicate(TruePredicate.getInstance());
        
        assertTrue(&quot;filterIterator should have an element&quot;, 
filterIterator.hasNext());
        
        filterIterator.setIterator(iter2);
        
        assertTrue(&quot;filterIterator should not have an element&quot;, !
filterIterator.hasNext());
    }&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;    /**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Test that when the predicate is changed, the hasNext method&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;returns the correct response for the new predicate.&lt;br/&gt;
     */&lt;br/&gt;
    public void testSetPredicate() 
{
        Iterator iter = Collections.singleton(null).iterator();
        
        FilterIterator filterIterator = new FilterIterator(iter);
        filterIterator.setPredicate(TruePredicate.getInstance());
        
        assertTrue(&quot;filterIterator should have an element&quot;, 
filterIterator.hasNext());
        
        filterIterator.setPredicate(NotNullPredicate.getInstance());
        
        assertTrue(&quot;filterIterator should not have an element&quot;, !
filterIterator.hasNext());
    }
&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;/pre&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342823">COLLECTIONS-61</key>
            <summary>[collections] FilterIterator doesn&apos;t reset when properties are set</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="huw12345@hotmail.com">Huw Roberts</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 30 Dec 2005 05:14:00 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:59 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:59 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.1</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12411165" author="jwcarman" created="Fri, 30 Dec 2005 05:25:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Aren&apos;t you asserting the opposite of what you want to test?  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;assertTrue(&quot;filterIterator should not have an element&quot;, !&lt;br/&gt;
filterIterator.hasNext());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Shouldn&apos;t this be:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;assertFalse(&quot;filterIterator should not have an element&quot;, !&lt;br/&gt;
filterIterator.hasNext());&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411166" author="huw12345@hotmail.com" created="Fri, 6 Jan 2006 08:32:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;(In reply to comment #1)&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; Aren&apos;t you asserting the opposite of what you want to test?  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t think so.  I admit that I&apos;m living in the past because I&apos;d forgotten &lt;br/&gt;
that JUnit has assertFalse (added about four years ago), but possibly the &lt;br/&gt;
formatting of my code has caused the confusion.  There&apos;s a &quot;!&quot; hanging at the &lt;br/&gt;
end of the line that means that the test does have the meaning I intend.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411167" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 7 Jan 2006 07:11:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed, thanks&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-60] Minor problems in SequencedHashMap and LRUMap</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-60</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;1.  The remove(Object) methods in the keySet and entrySet correctly remove null &lt;br/&gt;
keys, but incorrectly return false after they do so.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2.  The retainAll(Collection) and removeAll(Collection) methods in the &lt;br/&gt;
collection views do not properly modify the map&apos;s modCount, and thus will never &lt;br/&gt;
cause a ConcurrentModificationException.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-59] [collections] FastArrayList iterator method throwing ConcurrentModificationException in &apos;fast&apos; mode</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-59</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Please review the below code, I was under the impression that this not throw an&lt;br/&gt;
exception.&lt;/p&gt;



&lt;p&gt;Thanks,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Rob Cooke.&lt;/p&gt;



&lt;p&gt;----------------------------&lt;/p&gt;





&lt;p&gt;import org.apache.commons.collections.FastArrayList;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import java.util.Iterator;&lt;/p&gt;



&lt;p&gt;public class Test2 extends Thread{&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  public static void main(String argv[]) throws Exception&lt;/p&gt;
{

    FastArrayList array=new FastArrayList();

    array.add(&quot;this&quot;);

    array.add(&quot;is&quot;);

    array.add(&quot;a&quot;);

    new Test2(array).start();

    array.setFast(true);

    Thread.sleep(2000);

    array.add(&quot;test&quot;);

  }

&lt;p&gt;  protected FastArrayList array;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  public Test2(FastArrayList array)&lt;/p&gt;
{

    this.array=array;

  }

&lt;p&gt;  public void run(){&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    for(Iterator i=array.iterator();i.hasNext()&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;{&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;      try&lt;/p&gt;
{Thread.sleep(1000);}
&lt;p&gt;catch(Exception e){}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;      System.out.println(i.next());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Linux&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341519">COLLECTIONS-59</key>
            <summary>[collections] FastArrayList iterator method throwing ConcurrentModificationException in &apos;fast&apos; mode</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="cooker123456@yahoo.com">Robert Cooke</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 17 Jun 2004 06:55:03 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:59 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:59 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.2</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12406860" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Wed, 23 Jun 2004 04:19:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The code below should throw a ConcurrentModificationException. When using &lt;br/&gt;
collections you are not permitted to iterate and update a collection from &lt;br/&gt;
different threads.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;FastArrayList does allow add/remove/clear from different threads, but not &lt;br/&gt;
iteration. This is because iteration is not a single atomic operation.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406861" author="cooker123456@yahoo.com" created="Wed, 23 Jun 2004 05:18:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;What does the below implementation note for the FastArrayList.iterator() method&lt;br/&gt;
mean then?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks,&lt;br/&gt;
Rob.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;IMPLEMENTATION NOTE - If the list is operating in fast mode, an Iterator is&lt;br/&gt;
returned, and a structural modification to the list is made, then the Iterator&lt;br/&gt;
will continue over the previous contents of the list (at the time that the&lt;br/&gt;
Iterator was created), rather than failing due to concurrent modifications.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406862" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Wed, 23 Jun 2004 05:54:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It looks like your test code has a race condition. The line to setFast(true) is &lt;br/&gt;
after the thread start (which creates the iterator). This might be what you are &lt;br/&gt;
seeing.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In general, we would not advise relying on an implementation note as a &lt;br/&gt;
guarantee of behaviour.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406863" author="cooker123456@yahoo.com" created="Wed, 23 Jun 2004 07:09:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I just tried several cases including moving the setFast() method prior to the&lt;br/&gt;
start(). I also tried not using multiple threads at all.  It simply does not&lt;br/&gt;
work... If this is the case it&apos;s impossible to loop (thread safely) through all&lt;br/&gt;
the elements of the array while in fast mode.  This makes the list fairly useless.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks,&lt;br/&gt;
Rob.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406864" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Thu, 24 Jun 2004 04:48:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I took a proper look and found various holes. There was no easy full solution, &lt;br/&gt;
however I have managed to make some simple changes which greatly enhance &lt;br/&gt;
usability.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) Fast mode SubList iterator add() then set() and add() then remove() now &lt;br/&gt;
works correctly.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2) Fast mode Iterator add() doesn&apos;t break the iterator from then on.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;3) Fast mode now allows modification EITHER via the Iterator methods OR via the &lt;br/&gt;
List methods. Mixing them gives a ConcurrentModificationException.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;4) Some extra tests added.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Change in CVS, but won&apos;t be in 3.1 (unless 3.1 has to be rebuilt).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-58] [collections] [PATCH] patch to reduce object creation in CollectionUtils</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-58</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The attached patch reduces the number of Integer objects created when invoking&lt;br/&gt;
CollectionUtils.getCardinalityMap(final Collection col). The number of Integers&lt;br/&gt;
created is reduced by the count of unique objects within col.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The patch does not change the basic algorithm so the simplicity of the method is&lt;br/&gt;
not lost.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The change was profiled with the class below. These are the absolute times for&lt;br/&gt;
JDK 1.3.1_04 and 1.4.1_03&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;       1.4         1.3&lt;br/&gt;
pre:   168267      153849&lt;br/&gt;
post:  164473      150866&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;and normalised to the pre version for each JDK&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;       1.4         1.3&lt;br/&gt;
pre:   1.00        1.00&lt;br/&gt;
post:  0.98        0.98&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;so there was only a minor speed difference however the reduction in the number&lt;br/&gt;
of created objects has a memory use advantage. It was surprising to see that JDK&lt;br/&gt;
1.4.1 was slower than 1.3.1, in this limited test. The binaries were compiled&lt;br/&gt;
with JDK 1.4.1.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is the test class:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import org.apache.commons.collections.CollectionUtils ;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import java.util.*;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public class CollectionUtilsTest {&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;    Set a ;&lt;br/&gt;
    Set b ;&lt;br/&gt;
    Set c ;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Collection cols []  ;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    long startMillis ;&lt;br/&gt;
    void init () {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	a = new HashSet () ;&lt;br/&gt;
	for ( int i = 1 ; i &amp;lt;= 10000 ; i++ ) &lt;/p&gt;
{
	    a.add ( new Integer ( i ) ) ;
	}

&lt;p&gt;	b = new HashSet () ;&lt;br/&gt;
	for ( int i = 5001 ; i &amp;lt;= 15000 ; i++ ) &lt;/p&gt;
{
	    b.add ( new Integer ( i ) ) ;
	}

&lt;p&gt;	c = new HashSet () ;&lt;br/&gt;
	for ( int i = 1001 ; i &amp;lt;= 20000 ; i++ ) &lt;/p&gt;
{
	    c.add ( new Integer ( i ) ) ;
	}

&lt;p&gt;	cols = new Collection [] &lt;/p&gt;
{ a, b, c }
&lt;p&gt; ;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	startMillis = System.currentTimeMillis () ;&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;    void run () {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	for ( int i = 0 ; i &amp;lt; 3 ; i++ ) {&lt;br/&gt;
	    for ( int j = 0 ; j &amp;lt; 3 ; j++ ) &lt;/p&gt;
{
		CollectionUtils.union ( cols [ i ], cols [ j ] ) ;
		CollectionUtils.intersection ( cols [ i ], cols [ j ] ) ;
		CollectionUtils.disjunction ( cols [ i ], cols [ j ] ) ;
		CollectionUtils.subtract ( cols [ i ], cols [ j ] ) ;
	    }
&lt;p&gt;	}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    }&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;    void report () &lt;/p&gt;
{

	System.out.println ( &quot;Elapsed millis: &quot; + ( System.currentTimeMillis () -
startMillis ) ) ;
    }



&lt;p&gt;    public static void main ( String  [] arg ) &lt;/p&gt;
{

	CollectionUtilsTest t = new CollectionUtilsTest () ;

	t.init () ;
	t.run () ;
	t.report () ;

    }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-57] Addition of static class modifer to inner classes</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-57</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;findbugs 0.6.0 suggested that these classes had inner classes which could be&lt;br/&gt;
made static&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    CursorableLinkedList.java&lt;br/&gt;
    DefaultMapBag.java&lt;br/&gt;
    ExtendedProperties.java&lt;br/&gt;
    StaticBucketMap.java&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The attached patch file patches these classes in that way. After patching the&lt;br/&gt;
unit test passed okay.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m assuming the unit tests passing is proof enough that these changes are okay.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340801">COLLECTIONS-57</key>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-56] NoSuchElementException in ReferenceMap views</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-56</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The keySet() and values() views for the &lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.map.ReferenceMap class will throw a &lt;br/&gt;
NoSuchElementException in their toArray(Object[]) methods if any keys or values &lt;br/&gt;
have been reclaimed by the garbage collector and purge() has not been invoked.  &lt;br/&gt;
The toArray(Object[]) implementation inherited from &lt;br/&gt;
java.util.AbstractCollection uses size()&lt;del&gt;based iteration rather than hasNext()&lt;/del&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
based iteration.  This is inappropriate because the size of the map can change &lt;br/&gt;
during iteration.  The problem is exacerbated by the fact that neither the &lt;br/&gt;
KeySet nor Values classes purge stale elements from the list in their size() &lt;br/&gt;
methods.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The attached test case reliably reproduces this exception with Sun&apos;s 1.3.1_07 &lt;br/&gt;
and 1.4.2 Win2K Hotspot VMs.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The attached diff is a proposed fix for this issue.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;

            <title>[COLLECTIONS-55] [collections] Filling out PredicatedXXX Javadoc - a functor package.html</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-55</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In general Predicated collections and maps should probably be created before a &lt;br/&gt;
data structure has any contents.  Maybe this is just an artifact of the way I &lt;br/&gt;
use PredicatedList, but, nevertheless, I think all of the PredicatedXXX &lt;br/&gt;
classes need fuller JavaDoc - possibly pointing to an anchor in the &lt;br/&gt;
package.html for the functors package that talks about some scenarios for &lt;br/&gt;
using PredicatedXXX classes.  Right now we don&apos;t have a good in JavaDoc &lt;br/&gt;
explanation of the various ways to apply a Predicate to a collection.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;(I&apos;m on a Javadoc kick, sorry.)&lt;/p&gt;</description>

            <title>[COLLECTIONS-54] [collections][PATCH] increase number of tests run from 2484 to 7429</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-54</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The attached file patches build.xml to use &apos;TestAllPackages&apos; instead of&lt;br/&gt;
&apos;TestAll&apos; for the value of &apos;test.entry&apos;. This results in a greater number of&lt;br/&gt;
tests being run.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;project.xml also uses &apos;TestAll&apos; but there this patch does not fix that becuase I&lt;br/&gt;
am not using maven.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;(I find this situation a bit odd because Stephen Colebourne mentioned that some&lt;br/&gt;
bugs had been detected in o.a.c.collections.observed package a few days ago by&lt;br/&gt;
some tests and as far as I can see those tests would not have run without this&lt;br/&gt;
change. Is the use of ant deprecated or am I just not seeing something obvious&lt;br/&gt;
or customary?)&lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-53] [collections] Iterator.remove() in UnboundedFifoBuffer does not work</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-53</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The implementation of Iterator.remove() in the unbounded fifo buffer is buggy.&lt;br/&gt;
It produces an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundExceptions when it needs to swap around the&lt;br/&gt;
end of the array to its start.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The code should be:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;            public void remove() {&lt;br/&gt;
                if (lastReturnedIndex == -1) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                    throw new IllegalStateException();
                }

&lt;p&gt;                // First element can be removed quickly&lt;br/&gt;
                if (lastReturnedIndex == head) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                    UnboundedFifoBuffer.this.remove();
                    lastReturnedIndex = -1;
                    return;
                }

&lt;p&gt;                // Other elements require us to shift the subsequent elements&lt;br/&gt;
                /*&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;This loop is buggy in the original implementation!&lt;br/&gt;
                 */&lt;br/&gt;
                int i = lastReturnedIndex + 1;&lt;br/&gt;
                while (i != tail) 
{
                    buffer[decrement(i)] = buffer[i];
                    i = increment(i);
                }&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;                lastReturnedIndex = -1;&lt;br/&gt;
                tail = decrement(tail);&lt;br/&gt;
                buffer&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;tail&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; = null;&lt;br/&gt;
                index = decrement(index);&lt;br/&gt;
            }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;while the original buggy loop is:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;                // Other elements require us to shift the subsequent elements&lt;br/&gt;
                int i = lastReturnedIndex + 1;&lt;br/&gt;
                while (i != tail) {&lt;br/&gt;
                    if (i &amp;gt;= buffer.length) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                        buffer[i - 1] = buffer[0];
                        i = 0;
                    }
&lt;p&gt; else &lt;/p&gt;
{
                        buffer[i - 1] = buffer[i];
                        i++;
                    }
&lt;p&gt;                }&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342371">COLLECTIONS-53</key>
            <summary>[collections] Iterator.remove() in UnboundedFifoBuffer does not work</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-52] [collections] Method that add a Object to a Collection if it was not null</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-52</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;It would be a new static method to CollectionUtils class. It would retur &lt;br/&gt;
boolean because add() method from Collection returns a boolean. It would had &lt;br/&gt;
only a line:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public static boolean addNotNull(Collection c, Object o) {&lt;br/&gt;
   return (o != null)? c.add(o): false;&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Of course if c was null, it will throw a NullPointerException. &lt;br/&gt;
Aparently it is possible use a PredicatedCollection with NotNullPredicate. But &lt;br/&gt;
it will trhow a IllegalArgumentException if o was null. It is not interesting.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341563">COLLECTIONS-52</key>
            <summary>[collections] Method that add a Object to a Collection if it was not null</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-50] [collections] ExtendedProperties combine and pre unescaped strings-values</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-50</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If you have 2 extended props (prop1 &amp;amp; prop2). prop1 contains some or none&lt;br/&gt;
key/value pairs and prop2 contains at least one key with string value with&lt;br/&gt;
commas that doesn&apos;t already exist in prop1. N.B. This assumes both props were&lt;br/&gt;
loaded from property files and the string values in prop2 were escaped in the&lt;br/&gt;
file-system properties.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you call prop1.combine(prop2), the string-value from prop2 that contained&lt;br/&gt;
commas is treated as a non-escaped string and thus broken down into a Vector in&lt;br/&gt;
prop1. It should put the string-value into prop1 without procing the commas as&lt;br/&gt;
there were already processed by prop2 when it was loaded.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I believe that the combine method should merge the existing values from both&lt;br/&gt;
props and the putAll method should be overidden to overite existing keys in&lt;br/&gt;
prop1 from prop2 while maintaining the keysAsListed List.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341107">COLLECTIONS-50</key>
            <summary>[collections] ExtendedProperties combine and pre unescaped strings-values</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="dean.arnold@digitalunion.com">Dean Arnold</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 20 Nov 2003 17:42:18 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:58 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:58 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.1</version>

                                    <watches>0</watches>

                            <comment id="12405490" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Mon, 15 Mar 2004 01:32:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;All work on ExtendedProperties has migrated to the &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;configuration&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; project.&lt;/p&gt;

are required), however ExtendedProperties is effectively being treated as no-&lt;br/&gt;
change in &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;collections&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; until a &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;configuration&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; release, when it will be &lt;br/&gt;
deprecated.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-49] [collections] Compile Errors when Importing in VAJ 4</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-49</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;br/&gt;
when I try to import Collections Framework into IBM VisualAge for Java (VAJ) 4,&lt;br/&gt;
I get loads of Compile Errors. &lt;br/&gt;
(For your information: VAJ is Java 1.2.2 based...)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Most Errors are in the Testing Framework, so could be ignored.&lt;br/&gt;
However, there are quite a few Errors from using &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Entry &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;instead of&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Map.Entry,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;for Example in &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;AbstractReferenceMap&lt;br/&gt;
    public Object get(Object key) {&lt;br/&gt;
        purgeBeforeRead();&lt;br/&gt;
        Entry entry = getEntry(key);&lt;br/&gt;
        if (entry == null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return null;
        }
&lt;p&gt;        return entry.getValue();&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It would be nice for less adventurous users not to have to change the source&lt;br/&gt;
code in order to use this in VAJ. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I can send you the changed sources.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Yours,&lt;br/&gt;
David&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;P.S.: The severity &quot;major&quot; is debatable... 8-)&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows 2000&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342169">COLLECTIONS-49</key>
            <summary>[collections] Compile Errors when Importing in VAJ 4</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="dmueller@electronicpartner.de">David M&#252;ller</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 8 Apr 2005 18:48:22 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:58 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:58 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.1</version>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12409091" author="dmueller@electronicpartner.de" created="Fri, 8 Apr 2005 18:52:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Oh, I just found out, you could also add an import statement of &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import java.util.Map.Entry;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;to the Classes.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12409092" author="jwcarman" created="Mon, 9 May 2005 00:21:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Why do you have to import the source into VAJ in order to use Commons&lt;br/&gt;
Collections?  Can&apos;t you just use the binary version as a jar file on your classpath?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12409093" author="dmueller@electronicpartner.de" created="Mon, 9 May 2005 22:40:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;(In reply to comment #2)&lt;br/&gt;
I don&apos;t REALLY have to import the source for running the program, but as I was&lt;br/&gt;
debugging a shared cache using the LRUMap, I wanted to be able to step into the&lt;br/&gt;
collections methods.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12409094" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Mon, 23 May 2005 03:00:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The committers of &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;collections&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; have no simple means to test this problem (no&lt;br/&gt;
VAJ). While we would consider applying a cvs diff -u patch, that would only be a&lt;br/&gt;
temporary fix. As soon as we edited the file to make some other fix, the chances&lt;br/&gt;
are that we would break the VAJ code again.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Closing as wontfix.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12409095" author="tomdz" created="Mon, 23 May 2005 03:13:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;While I&apos;m not directly affected (havn&apos;t used VAJ for several years now), I find&lt;br/&gt;
this solution unsatisfactory. For one, while this may be a temporary solution it&lt;br/&gt;
would be a solution, and when the code gets broken again for VAJ, then another&lt;br/&gt;
bug can be raised.&lt;br/&gt;
Also, there is at least one easy way to make certain that Entry gets only used&lt;br/&gt;
as Map.Entry, and that is by incorporating PMD (&lt;a href=&quot;http://pmd.sourceforge.net&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://pmd.sourceforge.net&lt;/a&gt;) in&lt;br/&gt;
the build process and write a specific rule for Map.Entry. Perhaps David would&lt;br/&gt;
volunteer to write this rule ?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;WDYT ?&lt;br/&gt;
Tom&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12409096" author="jwcarman" created="Mon, 23 May 2005 04:14:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;My question is why is this a compile error with one compiler and not with&lt;br/&gt;
another?  Which one is correct by the JLS?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12409097" author="tomdz" created="Mon, 23 May 2005 04:22:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is most likely a bug in VAJ. A subclass inherits all accessible&lt;br/&gt;
(non-private) inner classes from its basetype just like it would inherit&lt;br/&gt;
accessible fields. Thus for subtypes of Map, its perfectly valid to access Entry&lt;br/&gt;
directly without the starting &quot;Map.&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12409098" author="jwcarman" created="Mon, 23 May 2005 04:26:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;So, why should we change code to work around a broken compiler in a tool that&lt;br/&gt;
very few folks use anymore?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12409099" author="tomdz" created="Mon, 23 May 2005 04:33:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;(In reply to comment #8)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Because its the right thing to do ? David has noted a problem that he has with&lt;br/&gt;
commons-collections, and he outlines the solution which is neither complicated&lt;br/&gt;
nor does break anything. He probably would even create a patch to fix it (there&lt;br/&gt;
shouldn&apos;t be too much problematic usages of Map.Entry). So why should we refuse&lt;br/&gt;
to incorporate it ?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12409100" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Mon, 23 May 2005 07:50:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;As I wrote before, if a patch is supplied, then we may apply it. But I agree&lt;br/&gt;
with James that this is low priority. &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;collections&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; has very limited committer&lt;br/&gt;
time, so sometimes we have to pick and choose which tasks to do.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12409101" author="tomdz" created="Mon, 23 May 2005 08:07:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;(In reply to comment #10)&lt;br/&gt;
My mistake, it didn&apos;t sound like you would accept a patch either.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12409102" author="dmueller@electronicpartner.de" created="Mon, 23 May 2005 16:07:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I was not aware this is a VAJ issue only, not a JDK 1.2.2 one also. &lt;br/&gt;
Still I think it&apos;s worth a patch as soon as I come to do it (haven&apos;t done this yet) &lt;br/&gt;
cvs diff -u, you say?&lt;br/&gt;
Anyway - I&apos;ll try.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-48] [collections] TransformedMap putAll(empty map) causes IllegalArgumentException</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-48</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If you create a TransformedMap, and then call map.putAll with an empty map as &lt;br/&gt;
an argument, an IllegalArgumentException is thrown.  putAll should be able to &lt;br/&gt;
handle empty maps without erroring.  The error occurs regardless of whether &lt;br/&gt;
the decorated map has any contents.  The implementation of the Transformers &lt;br/&gt;
attached does not matter.  I am using Java 1.4.2_07.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Example code:&lt;br/&gt;
Map map = TransformedMap.decorate(&lt;br/&gt;
        new HashMap(),&lt;br/&gt;
        TransformerUtils.nopTransformer(),&lt;br/&gt;
        TransformerUtils.nopTransformer());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;map.putAll(new HashMap()); // This causes IllegalArgumentException!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Fails with the following error:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Initial capacity must be greater than 0&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.collections.map.AbstractHashedMap.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
(AbstractHashedMap.java:142)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.collections.map.AbstractHashedMap.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
(AbstractHashedMap.java:127)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.collections.map.AbstractLinkedMap.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
(AbstractLinkedMap.java:95)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.collections.map.LinkedMap.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
(LinkedMap.java:78)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.collections.map.TransformedMap.transformMap&lt;br/&gt;
(TransformedMap.java:153)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.collections.map.TransformedMap.putAll&lt;br/&gt;
(TransformedMap.java:190)&lt;br/&gt;
	at net.carefx.contextagent.plugin.ldapuser.PluginTest.main&lt;br/&gt;
(PluginTest.java:71)&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342216">COLLECTIONS-48</key>
            <summary>[collections] TransformedMap putAll(empty map) causes IllegalArgumentException</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-46] [collections] CollectionUtils.transformedCollection(c,t) doesn&apos;t transform the elements of c</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-46</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;CollectionUtils.transformedCollection(c,t) doesn&apos;t transform the elements of c &lt;br/&gt;
as documented in the API.&lt;br/&gt;
The implementation passes this collection to &lt;br/&gt;
TransformedCollection.decorate(collection, transformer) &lt;br/&gt;
and further to&lt;br/&gt;
new TransformedCollection(coll, transformer);&lt;br/&gt;
where super(c) simply stored it WITHOUT conversion.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341605">COLLECTIONS-46</key>
            <summary>[collections] CollectionUtils.transformedCollection(c,t) doesn&apos;t transform the elements of c</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="gunnar.zarncke@tipp24.de">Gunnar Zarncke</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 30 Jul 2004 19:26:54 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:58 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:58 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.1</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12407131" author="cote@computer.org" created="Wed, 4 Aug 2004 00:11:45 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I wrote the following test case that seem to confirm the bug :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public void testTransformedCollection_2() &lt;/p&gt;
{
        List list = new ArrayList();
        list.add(&quot;1&quot;);
        list.add(&quot;2&quot;);
        list.add(&quot;3&quot;);
        Collection result = CollectionUtils.transformedCollection(list,
TRANSFORM_TO_INTEGER);
        assertTrue(&quot;returned object should be a TransformedCollection&quot;,
            result instanceof TransformedCollection);
        assertEquals(&quot;The transformed collection has the same size&quot;, 3,
result.size());
        assertTrue(&quot;The transformed collection contains the transformation of
the first elements&quot;,result.contains(new Integer(1)));
        assertTrue(&quot;The transformed collection contains the transformation of
the second elements&quot;,result.contains(new Integer(2)));
        assertTrue(&quot;The transformed collection contains the transformation of
the third elements&quot;,result.contains(new Integer(3)));
        assertFalse(&quot;The transformed collection doesn&apos;t contain the
transformation of the first elements&quot;,result.contains(&quot;1&quot;));
        assertFalse(&quot;The transformed collection doesn&apos;t contain  the
transformation of the second elements&quot;,result.contains(&quot;2&quot;));
        assertFalse(&quot;The transformed collection doesn&apos;t contain  the
transformation of the third elements&quot;,result.contains(&quot;3&quot;));
    }

&lt;p&gt;(I will provide a proper patch to TestCollectionUtils.java as soon as I get&lt;br/&gt;
cvsgrab working with my proxy.)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407132" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Wed, 4 Aug 2004 01:43:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The code is working as per the specification, see the factory method:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Factory method to create a transforming collection.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;p&amp;gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;If there are any elements already in the collection being decorated, they&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;are NOT transformed.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Elements already in the collection when the TransformedCollection is created &lt;br/&gt;
are not transformed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407133" author="gunnar.zarncke@tipp24.de" created="Wed, 4 Aug 2004 13:58:08 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This behavior of not transforming elements already present is not specified in &lt;br/&gt;
the CollectionUtils docs:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/collections/apidocs-&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/collections/apidocs-&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
COLLECTIONS_3_1/org/apache/commons/collections/CollectionUtils.html#transformedC&lt;br/&gt;
ollection(java.util.Collection,%20org.apache.commons.collections.Transformer)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Besides, how else am I supposed to transform (read: map) a Collection other &lt;br/&gt;
than with that method? &lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12407134" author="cote@computer.org" created="Wed, 4 Aug 2004 20:07:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=12326)&lt;br/&gt;
Comments of the method transformedCollection&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407135" author="cote@computer.org" created="Wed, 4 Aug 2004 20:19:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I agree with you, it would be better if somebody copy paste the two line saying&lt;br/&gt;
that the elements already in the collection being decorated are NOT transformed.&lt;br/&gt;
 Actually, I find the javadoc of the method pretty confusing.  I&apos;ll try to&lt;br/&gt;
improve it and I&apos;ll submit a patch.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t think there is anything to apply a tranformer to the elements of a&lt;br/&gt;
collections. Maybe, you should submit a rfe for a new transformer.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-45] [collections] ReferenceMap size of bug.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-45</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I have the following declaration of my map:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here is the code:&lt;br/&gt;
System.err.println(&quot;elements are &quot; + elements + &quot;\n\t  element size is &quot; + &lt;br/&gt;
elements.size() + &quot;\n\tkey set &quot; + elements.keySet()  + &quot;\n\telements:&quot; + &lt;br/&gt;
elements.values());&lt;br/&gt;
Iterator iter = elements.keySet().iterator();&lt;br/&gt;
       while (iter.hasNext()) &lt;/p&gt;
{
	Object element =  iter.next();
	System.err.println(&quot;next element:&quot; + element);
	}
&lt;p&gt;        System.err.println(&quot;--------------&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
Here is the results below, where usually the answer is 2 but occationally 3&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;elements are &lt;/p&gt;
{Concept=ConceptImpl Concept, ValueSet=ConceptImpl ValueSet}
&lt;p&gt; element size is 3&lt;br/&gt;
key set &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;Concept, ValueSet&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
elements:&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;ConceptImpl Concept, ConceptImpl ValueSet&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
next element:Concept&lt;br/&gt;
next element:ValueSet&lt;br/&gt;
--------------&lt;br/&gt;
size:3&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342917">COLLECTIONS-45</key>
            <summary>[collections] ReferenceMap size of bug.</summary>

                            <comment id="12411445" author="gudnabrsam@yahoo.com" created="Thu, 16 Feb 2006 04:36:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Version?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411446" author="hemilycrutcher@yahoo.com" created="Thu, 16 Feb 2006 20:48:08 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It is version 3.1.  I have a feeling the problem is that the week reference is &lt;br/&gt;
still counted in the size, but is skipped over in the iteration. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411447" author="gudnabrsam@yahoo.com" created="Fri, 17 Feb 2006 04:17:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Is your map being used by &amp;gt; 1 thread?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411448" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Fri, 3 Mar 2006 04:18:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It is likely that this is the correct behaviour, as ReferenceMap specifically&lt;br/&gt;
exists to release keys and values when they are no longer referenced by the rest&lt;br/&gt;
of the program. Since this gc can occur at any point in time, there can be a&lt;br/&gt;
difference between the size seen in an iteration as opposed to the size seen via&lt;br/&gt;
size().&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please reopen with a full junit test case if you believe you are seeing a&lt;br/&gt;
genuine error.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-44] Upgrade your version number</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-44</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Can you update your build xml to modify the component.version property.&lt;br/&gt;
It is actually setted to 2.0 and should be to 3.0 dev or 2.1 dev ??&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Futhermore, the Manifest file is not automatically generated from build.xml &lt;br/&gt;
properties.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I attach a copy of the build.xml and the Manifest files that I modified to &lt;br/&gt;
automatically update the release number.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I let you to choose which number to use in the build.xml.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here are diffs that I done from Cygwin because I can&apos;t access to the CVS &lt;br/&gt;
Repository from my office &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/sad.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;diff MANIFEST.MF :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;5c5&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt; Implementation-Version: @version@&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;#8212;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; Implementation-Version: 2.0&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;diff build.xml :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;97,99d96&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;       &amp;lt;echo message=&quot;-------- ${Name-Long} ${component.version} --------&quot;/&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;       &amp;lt;filter  token=&quot;version&quot;               value=&quot;${component.version}&quot;/&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt; &lt;br/&gt;
254,256c251&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;       &amp;lt;mkdir dir=&quot;${workdir}/classes&quot;/&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;       &amp;lt;mkdir dir=&quot;${workdir}/conf&quot;/&amp;gt;      &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;       &amp;lt;copy todir=&quot;${workdir}/classes&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;#8212;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt;       &amp;lt;copy todir=&quot;${workdir}&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
261,263d255&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;       &amp;lt;copy  todir=&quot;${workdir}/conf&quot; filtering=&quot;on&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;          &amp;lt;fileset dir=&quot;${source.src}/conf&quot; includes=&quot;*.MF&quot;/&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;       &amp;lt;/copy&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
268c260&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;       &amp;lt;jar jarfile=&quot;${dest.jardir.jar}&quot; &lt;br/&gt;
manifest=&quot;${workdir}/conf/MANIFEST.MF&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;#8212;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt;       &amp;lt;jar jarfile=&quot;${dest.jardir.jar}&quot; &lt;br/&gt;
manifest=&quot;${source.src}/conf/MANIFEST.MF&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

            <title>[COLLECTIONS-43] [collections] serialVersionUID should be private</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-43</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The following classes define serialVersionUID with default (package) access:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;HashBag&lt;br/&gt;
TreeBag&lt;br/&gt;
functors.*&lt;br/&gt;
NodeCachingLinkedList&lt;br/&gt;
LRUMap&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This field should be defined as private.&lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-42] [collections] PriorityBuffer iterator does not remove elements properly</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-42</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The following code snippet:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;System.out.println(&quot;----------&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
PriorityBuffer s = new PriorityBuffer();&lt;br/&gt;
s.add(new Integer(1));&lt;br/&gt;
s.add(new Integer(2));&lt;br/&gt;
s.add(new Integer(3));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;for (Iterator it = s.iterator(); it.hasNext(); s.remove() )&lt;br/&gt;
	System.out.println(it.next());&lt;br/&gt;
System.out.println(&quot;----------&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Prints this:&lt;br/&gt;
----------&lt;br/&gt;
1&lt;br/&gt;
3&lt;br/&gt;
----------&lt;br/&gt;
Element 2 is lost, contrary to javadoc of java.util.Iterator&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342084">COLLECTIONS-42</key>
            <summary>[collections] PriorityBuffer iterator does not remove elements properly</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="5">Cannot Reproduce</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bobik72@freenet.de">Dusan Chromy</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 2 Mar 2005 01:11:53 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:58 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:58 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.1</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12408792" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Wed, 23 Mar 2005 08:06:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The javadoc for PriorityBuffer states that the iterator may return results in a&lt;br/&gt;
random order, so there is no issue there.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Your code sample, is repeatable on my system, however it uses the remove method&lt;br/&gt;
of the map within the iterator. As a general rule for collections, you may not&lt;br/&gt;
alter the collection while you are iterating through it, except via the iterator&lt;br/&gt;
remove method.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thus, I suspect that you reported this because you used s.remove() in the code&lt;br/&gt;
example when you should have used it.remove().&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">
                        <customfieldname>Attachment count</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>0.0</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        <customfield id="customfield_10010" key="com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:importid">
                        <customfieldname>Bugzilla Id</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>33791</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310220" key="com.atlassian.jira.ext.charting:firstresponsedate">
                        <customfieldname>Date of First Response</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>Wed, 23 Mar 2005 08:06:42 +0000</customfieldvalue>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310420" key="com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank">
                        <customfieldname>Global Rank</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>18956</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-41] LazyCollections.lazyList.get(i) grows wrong</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-41</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;LazyCollections.lazyList.get&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/information.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; grows wrong when called with i == (size() -1).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If the list has 3 elements and LazyCollections.lazyList.get(2) is called then &lt;br/&gt;
size of the list will grow to size == 4 because within bounds check says:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;if(index &amp;lt; (this.listImpl.size()-1) {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Should be:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;if(index &amp;lt; this.listImpl.size()) {&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340285">COLLECTIONS-41</key>
            <summary>LazyCollections.lazyList.get(i) grows wrong</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-40] ExtendedProperties.load should default to encoding &quot;8859_1&quot;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-40</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The default load method for commons.collections.ExtendedProperties currently &lt;br/&gt;
loads properties using the default JVM encoding.  The default load() method &lt;br/&gt;
should use &quot;8859_1&quot; encoding.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Rationale:&lt;br/&gt;
1) consistency: java.util.Properties.load() method always uses &quot;8859_1&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
2) properties resources are always 8859_1, by convention.&lt;br/&gt;
2) On edbcic machines, particularly IBM mainframes, the default encoding is &lt;br/&gt;
Cp1047 (ebcdic), but properties files are always ASCII (ISO8859-1)&lt;br/&gt;
3) This bug causes many Apache tools, such as Velocity, which uses &lt;br/&gt;
commons.collections, to fail on non-ascii machines, since they distribute &lt;br/&gt;
properties resources which are (correctly) in 8859-1.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340577">COLLECTIONS-40</key>
            <summary>ExtendedProperties.load should default to encoding &quot;8859_1&quot;</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="kirk@wolf-associates.com">Kirk Wolf</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 4 Mar 2003 03:47:28 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:58 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:58 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.1</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12403757" author="amamment" created="Thu, 13 Mar 2003 01:01:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=5291)&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;PATCH&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Update to always attempt using ISO-8859-1&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403758" author="amamment" created="Thu, 13 Mar 2003 01:03:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m submitting a patch which should resolve this problem.  If the encoding is &lt;br/&gt;
null (the case for load()), or the supplied encoding is not supported, the &lt;br/&gt;
Property file is loaded with encoding ISO-8859-1.  If this encoding is not &lt;br/&gt;
supported (and support is required for all java platforms), only then is the &lt;br/&gt;
platform default encoding is used....&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403759" author="dlr" created="Wed, 19 Mar 2003 04:48:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Is this fix also applicable to Commons Configuration?  Strikes me that it would&lt;br/&gt;
be, but I haven&apos;t verified.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403760" author="rwaldhoff@apache.org" created="Sat, 19 Apr 2003 06:20:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch applied, thanks Arun and Kirk.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;By the way, it seems to me that if one calls load(InputStream in,String&lt;br/&gt;
encoding) with some non-null encoding then we shouldn&apos;t be attempting other&lt;br/&gt;
encodings (what if some other encoding &quot;works&quot; but isn&apos;t right?), but this isn&apos;t&lt;br/&gt;
substantially different from the previous behavior.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403761" author="dlr" created="Sat, 19 Apr 2003 07:48:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Rodney, yeah, an IllegalArgumentException might be more appropriate.  Unless&lt;br/&gt;
perhaps the non-null encoding is an empty string, in which case falling back to&lt;br/&gt;
the JVM default or UTF-8 might make sense.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                            <attachment id="12332162" name="ASF.LICENSE.NOT.GRANTED--ExtendedPropertiesPatch.txt" size="1328" author="amamment" created="Thu, 13 Mar 2003 01:01:27 +0000"/>
                    </attachments>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-39] [collections] ExtendedProperties should not just allow NPEs</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-39</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Its really an annoyance because I frequently have my debugger stop on&lt;br/&gt;
NullPointerException.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ExtendedProperties.readProperty&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Change from         &lt;br/&gt;
                    String line = readLine().trim();&lt;br/&gt;
to&lt;br/&gt;
                    String line = readLine();&lt;br/&gt;
                    if(line != null) line = line.trim(); else return null;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also in ExtendedProperties.load&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;            while (true) {&lt;br/&gt;
                String line = reader.readProperty();&lt;br/&gt;
				if(line == null)&lt;br/&gt;
					return;&lt;br/&gt;
                int equalSign = line.indexOf(&apos;=&apos;);&lt;/p&gt;</description>

                            <comment id="12407317" author="d.tonhofer@m-plify.com" created="Tue, 24 Aug 2004 17:02:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;That&apos;s right, I was not very specific:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you are on &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/collections/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/collections/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

                            <comment id="12407318" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Wed, 25 Aug 2004 01:31:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It was exactly what I intended &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The source distro contains the jar file and the source code, which is far more &lt;br/&gt;
useful to plug in to an IDE like Eclipse than the binary distro (ie. you need &lt;br/&gt;
the source code to make the best use of commons IMHO)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

            <title>[COLLECTIONS-36] [collections] MultiHashMap.remove(key, value) always returns a value</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-36</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;According to the documentation, MultiHashMap.remove(key, value) will only return&lt;br/&gt;
a value when it removes a value, null if nothing was removed. Instead, it always&lt;br/&gt;
returns a value.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Linux&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

            <title>[COLLECTIONS-35] [collections] IteratorChain.hasNext() throws when chain is empty</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-35</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If added to TestIteratorChain, the following test case fails with the stack&lt;br/&gt;
trace that follows.  The exception is documented in the javadoc for&lt;br/&gt;
IteratorChain.hasNext(), but the behavior may be inconsistent with the Iterator&lt;br/&gt;
interface spec.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Test case:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public void testEmptyChainHasNext() &lt;/p&gt;
{
        IteratorChain chain = new IteratorChain();
        assertTrue(!chain.hasNext());      
    }

&lt;p&gt;Stack trace:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Time: 20.733&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; There was 1 error:&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 1)&lt;br/&gt;
testEmptyChainHasNext(org.apache.commons.collections.iterators.TestIteratorChain)&lt;br/&gt;
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException: IteratorChains must contain at least&lt;br/&gt;
one Iterator&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.iterators.IteratorChain.checkChainIntegrity(IteratorChain.java:248)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.iterators.IteratorChain.lockChain(IteratorChain.java:256)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.iterators.IteratorChain.hasNext(IteratorChain.java:295)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.iterators.TestIteratorChain.testEmptyChainHasNext(TestIteratorChain.java:186)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at&lt;br/&gt;
sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at&lt;br/&gt;
sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)&lt;/p&gt;</description>

Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-34] Collections doesn&apos;t build with jdk1.2 javac</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-34</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Just tried building jakarta-commons/collections from CVS (12/5), and it doesn&apos;t&lt;br/&gt;
compile with Sun&apos;s &apos;javac&apos; for linux:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;$ java -version&lt;br/&gt;
java version &quot;1.2.2&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
Classic VM (build JDK-1.2.2_007, green threads, nojit)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;$ ant clean ; ant&lt;br/&gt;
....&lt;br/&gt;
build-java:&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;mkdir&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Created dir:&lt;br/&gt;
/home/jeff/apache/jakarta/jakarta-commons/collections/dist/classes&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Compiling 26 source files to&lt;br/&gt;
/home/jeff/apache/jakarta/jakarta-commons/collections/dist/classes&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
/home/jeff/apache/jakarta/jakarta-commons/collections/src/java/org/apache/commons/collections/FastTreeMap.java:325:&lt;br/&gt;
Inner type Entry in class java.util.TreeMap not accessible from class&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.FastTreeMap.&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;                 Entry e = (Entry) i.next();&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;                 ^&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
....&lt;br/&gt;
BUILD FAILED&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;However, it &lt;b&gt;does&lt;/b&gt; work if I set build.compiler=jikes. It also works if I use&lt;br/&gt;
jdk1.3 &apos;javac&apos;. Possibly a bug in javac?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Anyway, just thought I&apos;d bring this to people&apos;s attention, as the STATUS.html&lt;br/&gt;
file states it needs &quot;JDK1.2 or later&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;thanks,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;--Jeff&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Linux&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-33] [collections] AbstractHashedMap: initial threshold too conservative</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-33</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The (int initialCapacity, float loadFactor) constructor of&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.map.AbstractHashedMap calculates the initial&lt;br/&gt;
resize too threshold conservatively, based on the requested initial capacity&lt;br/&gt;
instead of the actually chosen initial capacity (which is round up to the next&lt;br/&gt;
power of too). This could be fixed switching two lines to calculating the&lt;br/&gt;
initial threshold after rounding up the capacity instead of before:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;#8212; AbstractHashedMap.java      2005-05-22 17:04:23.000000000 +0200&lt;br/&gt;
+++ AbstractHashedMap-patched.java      2005-05-22 17:08:46.000000000 +0200&lt;br/&gt;
@@ -147,4 +147,4 @@&lt;br/&gt;
         this.loadFactor = loadFactor;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;this.threshold = calculateThreshold(initialCapacity, loadFactor);&lt;br/&gt;
         initialCapacity = calculateNewCapacity(initialCapacity);&lt;br/&gt;
+        this.threshold = calculateThreshold(initialCapacity, loadFactor);&lt;br/&gt;
         this.data = new HashEntry&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;initialCapacity&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;A map with an requested capacity of 600 and a load factor of 0.75, will start&lt;br/&gt;
with an initial array of length 1024. Without the fix, the array will be resized&lt;br/&gt;
for the first time as soon as there are 450 entries, i.e. the array is less than&lt;br/&gt;
45% filled instead of the 75% suggested by the load factor.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342254">COLLECTIONS-33</key>
            <summary>[collections] AbstractHashedMap: initial threshold too conservative</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-32] [collections] DualTreeBidiMap does not  sort with custom Comparator</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-32</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When you supply a Comparator to the constructor of DualTreeBidiMap, the custom&lt;br/&gt;
sorting order is NOT maintained. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The problem lies in the order where &lt;br/&gt;
    protected Map createMap()&lt;br/&gt;
is called: The constructors in AbstractDualBidiMap call this metod, but the&lt;br/&gt;
comparator is set &lt;b&gt;after&lt;/b&gt; calling super() in DualTreeBidiMap:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;//--- Class AbstractDualBidiMap---// &lt;br/&gt;
    protected AbstractDualBidiMap() &lt;/p&gt;
{
        super();
        maps[0] = createMap();
        maps[1] = createMap();
    }
&lt;p&gt;//--- Class DualTreeBidiMap ---// &lt;br/&gt;
    public DualTreeBidiMap(Comparator comparator) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        super();
        this.comparator = comparator; // &amp;lt;-- Too late, createMap already called!
    }
&lt;p&gt;    protected Map createMap() &lt;/p&gt;
{
        return new TreeMap(comparator); // &amp;lt;-- Comparator always null
    }


&lt;p&gt;Hence, DualTreeBidiMap.compatator() always returns null.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341505">COLLECTIONS-32</key>
            <summary>[collections] DualTreeBidiMap does not  sort with custom Comparator</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jonas.vanpoucke@actonomy.com">Jonas Van Poucke</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 11 Jun 2004 15:47:05 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:58 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:58 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.0</version>
