                            <comment id="12406819" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 12 Jun 2004 06:32:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;protected Map createMap() is a lousy design &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/sad.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;(&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have changed CVS with updated AbstractDualBidiMap, DualHashBidiMap and &lt;br/&gt;
DualTreeBidiMap. If you have a chance to get these from CSV and test them I &lt;br/&gt;
would be grateful.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406820" author="jonas.vanpoucke@actonomy.com" created="Mon, 14 Jun 2004 15:01:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;br/&gt;
I did a quick test for DualTreeBidiMap and everything seems to work as expected.&lt;br/&gt;
Thanks! &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I also included some code for the JUnit test (add the following to&lt;br/&gt;
TestDualTreeBidiMap2):&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;//--- Additional JUnit method start ---//&lt;br/&gt;
  public void testSortOrder() throws Exception {&lt;br/&gt;
    SortedBidiMap sm = (SortedBidiMap) makeFullMap();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    // Sort by the comparator used in the makeEmptyBidiMap() method&lt;br/&gt;
    List newSortedKeys = Arrays.asList(getSampleKeys());&lt;br/&gt;
    Collections.sort(newSortedKeys,&lt;br/&gt;
                     new ReverseComparator(ComparableComparator.getInstance()));&lt;br/&gt;
    newSortedKeys = Collections.unmodifiableList(newSortedKeys);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Iterator mapIter = sm.keySet().iterator();&lt;br/&gt;
    Iterator expectedIter = newSortedKeys.iterator();&lt;br/&gt;
    while (expectedIter.hasNext()) &lt;/p&gt;
{
      Object expectedKey = expectedIter.next();
      Object mapKey = mapIter.next();
      assertNotNull(&quot;key in sorted list may not be null&quot;, expectedKey);
      assertNotNull(&quot;key in map may not be null&quot;, mapKey);
      assertEquals(&quot;key from sorted list and map must be equal&quot;, expectedKey,
                   mapKey);
    }
&lt;p&gt;  }&lt;br/&gt;
//--- Additional JUnit method end---//&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

            <title>[COLLECTIONS-30] [collections] TransformedMap.putAll fails with empty Map</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-30</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Using collections 3.1, TransformedMap.putAll creates a new LinkedMap with the&lt;br/&gt;
size of the parameter&apos;s collection as capacity. When this size is zero, however,&lt;br/&gt;
this raises exceptions.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;paul&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-28] SequencedHashMap.indexOf(Object key) throws annoying exceptions</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-28</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Is it intentional that SequencedHashMap.indexOf(Object key) throws a &lt;br/&gt;
NullPointerException when the key does not exist in the map?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Shouldn&apos;t it return -1 in those situations?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here is an addition to the TestSequencedHashMap which examplifies the problem&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public void testIndexOf() throws Exception {&lt;br/&gt;
  Object[] keys = getKeys();&lt;br/&gt;
  int expectedSize = keys.length;&lt;br/&gt;
  Object[] values = getValues();&lt;br/&gt;
  for (int i = 0; i &amp;lt; expectedSize; i++) &lt;/p&gt;
{
    labRat.put(keys[i], values[i]);
  }
&lt;p&gt;  // test that the index returned are in the same order that they were &lt;br/&gt;
  // placed in the map&lt;br/&gt;
  for (int i=0;i&amp;lt;keys.length;i++) &lt;/p&gt;
{
    assertEquals(&quot;indexOf with existing key failed&quot;,i,labRat.indexOf(keys[i]));
  }
&lt;p&gt;  // test non existing key..&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  assertEquals(&quot;test with non-existing key failed&quot;,-1,labRat.indexOf&lt;br/&gt;
(&quot;NonExistingKey&quot;));&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340373">COLLECTIONS-28</key>
            <summary>SequencedHashMap.indexOf(Object key) throws annoying exceptions</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>

            <title>[COLLECTIONS-27] [collections] LRUMap.clone() broken?</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-27</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;LRUMap.clone() always produces an empty Map. Shouldn&apos;t it produce a shallow &lt;br/&gt;
copy with all the entries?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This test actually fails in 3.0:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public void testLRUMapClone()&lt;/p&gt;
    {
        LRUMap lru = new LRUMap(10);
        lru.put(&quot;1&quot;, &quot;1&quot;);

        Map lruClone = (Map) lru.clone();

        assertEquals(lru.size(), lruClone.size());
    }</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;

                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-26</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>

            <title>[COLLECTIONS-25] [collections][PATCH] OutOfMemoryError test case for MapUtils.verbosePrint.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-25</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The attached patch adds a test case to TestMapUtils that demonstrates infinite&lt;br/&gt;

                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;

        <key id="12340954">COLLECTIONS-25</key>
            <summary>[collections][PATCH] OutOfMemoryError test case for MapUtils.verbosePrint.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12405025" author="janekdb@yahoo.co.uk" created="Wed, 10 Sep 2003 04:03:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=8120)&lt;br/&gt;
demonstrates infinite&lt;br/&gt;
patch demonstrating recursion in MapUtils.verbosePrint&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405026" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Wed, 10 Sep 2003 05:02:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;All we need now is the fix for the newly demonstrated bug....&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405027" author="phil@steitz.com" created="Wed, 10 Sep 2003 11:47:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Is this really a bug??&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As a user, I would personally not complain about a documented limitation/warning&lt;br/&gt;
that this method should not be used for maps that may contain cyclic object&lt;br/&gt;
graphs.  I agree that infinite recursions are evil, but if you want to ask for&lt;br/&gt;
recursive traversals... As the javadoc states, &quot;When the value is a Map,&lt;br/&gt;
recursive behaviour occurs.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Otherwise what are the choices?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1. limit the depth of the recursion&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2. hold an array of visited nodes and check each new node against the visited&lt;br/&gt;
list to prevent cycles&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;3. put some other absolute limit on the number of nodes visited&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Options 1 and 3 are ugly.  I suppose that I could live with 2., but do we really&lt;br/&gt;
need to do this?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I suppose we could also consider dumping the recursive contract &amp;#8211; i.e., just&lt;br/&gt;
iterate and print the map entries, eliminating the quoted line above from the&lt;br/&gt;
javadoc.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405028" author="amamment" created="Wed, 10 Sep 2003 23:56:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;As the result of a previous submission of patches (&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-82&quot; title=&quot;[collections] Map.debugPrint improvements&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;COLLECTIONS-82&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;COM-635&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;) I already had &lt;br/&gt;
planned some work to prevent this kind of recursion.  I attach a patch which &lt;br/&gt;
actually does multiple things....&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) Modifies test cases to make duplicate any tests available for debugPrint &lt;br/&gt;
apply to verbosePrint and vice-versa (there were a few tests present for one &lt;br/&gt;
and not the other, and it seemed easy to do).  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2) Updates verbosePrintInternal to also pass an internal stack of previously &lt;br/&gt;
visited maps.  If a previously visited map is seen again, the text &quot;(ancestor&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;i&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Map) is printed out as the value of the Map, where i refers to level of &lt;br/&gt;
ancestor - the parent of the current Map is 0, the parent&apos;s parent 1, and so &lt;br/&gt;
on.... &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;3) Modified the test in the previously attached patch (&amp;lt;a &lt;br/&gt;
href=&quot;showattachment.cgi?attach_id=8120&quot;&amp;gt;attachment=8120&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;); effectively &lt;br/&gt;
replacing it with an alternate version that tests for the behaviour mentioned &lt;br/&gt;
in #2 above.  If the test is executed on unmodified code, an OutOfMemory error &lt;br/&gt;
should be generated as previously.  Also added an equivalent test for &lt;br/&gt;
verbosePrint.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Area of Concern 1 - the mechanism used for preventing infinitely recursive &lt;br/&gt;
printing makes sense to me.  However, the exact notation for the text to print &lt;br/&gt;
out when an ancestor map is included within the current map was something that &lt;br/&gt;
I made up.  Anyone have better suggestions?  I just tried to go with something &lt;br/&gt;
like the &quot;(this Map)&quot; text used for identifying the current map when one is &lt;br/&gt;
included within itself.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Area of Concern 2 - The code recursively passes a stack of previously &lt;br/&gt;
navigated maps along with the recursive call to print child maps.  Each &lt;br/&gt;
element of the child&apos;s values is checked for existence in the stack in order &lt;br/&gt;
to determine if the notation listed above should be used.  However, the check &lt;br/&gt;
is done with Stack.contains().  Is this guaranteed to work?  I &lt;br/&gt;
assume .contains calls .equals on members of the stack to determine if any &lt;br/&gt;
specific element is already present.  I&apos;m not sure what the guarantees are &lt;br/&gt;
when you call .equals on a self-referencing Map.  It worked for the testcase &lt;br/&gt;
with a TreeMap on the IBM JDK 1.3, but will it work in general?    &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405029" author="amamment" created="Wed, 10 Sep 2003 23:57:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=8130)&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;Patch&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Updates to verbosePrintInternal to handle recursion - deprecates previous patch&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405030" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Thu, 18 Sep 2003 03:19:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch applied, however Stack uses .equals() as you mentioned, and we should be &lt;br/&gt;
using == really. But its an unusual case, so I&apos;m not that bothered.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

            <title>[COLLECTIONS-24] [collections] [patch] TransformingPredicate</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-24</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;A Predicate which transforms the given object before evaluating the result with&lt;br/&gt;
another Predicate :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public boolean evaluate(Object object) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        Object result = transformer.transform(object);
        return predicate.evaluate(result);
    }</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-23] BeanMap.putAll(beanmap) fails</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-23</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I created two beanmaps, both around objects of the same class, to try to&lt;br/&gt;
effectively clone the underlying objects (this was before I looked harder and&lt;br/&gt;
realized that BeanMap.clone() would try to instantiate a new object on its own).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I found that this fails with a java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: The bean of&lt;br/&gt;
type: com.isx.isaf.IsafAgentDescription has no property called: class&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The reason: BeanMap&apos;s underlying introspector notices the read-only property of&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;class&quot; (the class of the bean object), and has a get() entry for it that has&lt;br/&gt;
no matching put.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When AbstractMap.putAll iterates through the values, it tries to put() the class&lt;br/&gt;
value and this causes the failure.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The workarounds is to reimplement putAll() outside the map and catch exceptions &lt;br/&gt;
for every failed put (this should be the only one unless the bean itself has &lt;br/&gt;
other read-only properties).  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;BeanMap.clone() correctly checks for read-only properties and doesn&apos;t try to &lt;br/&gt;
set them, but is limited to beans that have zero-parameter constructors; its &lt;br/&gt;
real problem is that it is still &quot;protected&quot; in BeanMap, not public.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Possible fix is to override putAll() from AbstractMap and check if the&lt;br/&gt;
property is read-only before calling put() and ignoring it if it is.  Options&lt;br/&gt;
involving fixing put() itself would cause more problems than solutions, IMHO.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Another fix is to catch the &quot;class&quot; property and filter it out completely so&lt;br/&gt;
it never shows up in the keySet or entrySet at all.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340278">COLLECTIONS-23</key>
            <summary>BeanMap.putAll(beanmap) fails</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="acroyear@io.com">Joe Shelby</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 30 Jul 2002 03:08:05 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:57 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:57 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12402801" author="pjack@sfaf.org" created="Sat, 10 Aug 2002 09:06:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Added a putAllWriteable(BeanMap) method that will let you only copy the&lt;br/&gt;
writeable properties.  Didn&apos;t want to override putAll(Map) because it would&lt;br/&gt;
break backwards compatibility, and in most cases it really is an exception to&lt;br/&gt;
try to put a read-only property.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>

                            <customfieldvalue>0.0</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>

                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In BeanMap.initialize() method there is a bug that causes all properties to have write methods &lt;br/&gt;
(even if they are null).&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-21] TestMap.tearDown() should throw Exception</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-21</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;TestMap.tearDown() overrides TestCase.tearDown(). The original method throws an&lt;br/&gt;
Exception, however the redeclared method doesn&apos;t. This means that methods which&lt;br/&gt;
override TestMap.tearDown() cannot throw an Exception. In my case, I&apos;m creating&lt;br/&gt;
and removing a test database in the setUp() and tearDown() so an Exception could&lt;br/&gt;
easily be thrown.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I realise that TestMap isn&apos;t part of Collections&apos; public API, however I thought&lt;br/&gt;
I&apos;d mention this in case other people want to reuse your excellent testing code.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340393">COLLECTIONS-21</key>
            <summary>TestMap.tearDown() should throw Exception</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="rich@rd.gen.nz">Rich Dougherty</reporter>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-20] [collections] TestObservedBag and TestObservedSet fail under Java 1.3.1</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-20</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;With CVS HEAD of 2003-Sept-16 two unit tests fail under Java 1.3.1_04.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  $ java -version&lt;br/&gt;
  java version &quot;1.3.1_04&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
  Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.3.1_04-b02)&lt;br/&gt;
  Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.3.1_04-b02, mixed mode)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The stack trace is:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; There were 2 failures:&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 1) testObservedSet(o.a.c.collections.observed.TestObservedBag)&lt;br/&gt;
junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: expected same:&amp;lt;7&amp;gt; was not:&amp;lt;6&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;     at&lt;br/&gt;
o.a.c.collections.observed.ObservedTestHelper.doTestRemoveIterated(ObservedTestHelper.java:933)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;     at&lt;br/&gt;
o.a.c.collections.observed.ObservedTestHelper.bulkTestObservedCollection(ObservedTestHelper.java:156)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;     at&lt;br/&gt;
o.a.c.collections.observed.ObservedTestHelper.bulkTestObservedBag(ObservedTestHelper.java:188)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;     at&lt;br/&gt;
o.a.c.collections.observed.TestObservedBag.testObservedSet(TestObservedBag.java:98)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 2) testObservedSet(o.a.c.collections.observed.TestObservedSet)&lt;br/&gt;
junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: expected same:&amp;lt;7&amp;gt; was not:&amp;lt;6&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;     at&lt;br/&gt;
o.a.c.collections.observed.ObservedTestHelper.doTestRemoveIterated(ObservedTestHelper.java:933)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;     at&lt;br/&gt;
o.a.c.collections.observed.ObservedTestHelper.bulkTestObservedCollection(ObservedTestHelper.java:156)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;     at&lt;br/&gt;
o.a.c.collections.observed.ObservedTestHelper.bulkTestObservedSet(ObservedTestHelper.java:164)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;     at&lt;br/&gt;
o.a.c.collections.observed.TestObservedSet.testObservedSet(TestObservedSet.java:106)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; FAILURES!!!&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Tests run: 7489,  Failures: 2,  Errors: 0&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;It doesn&apos;t matter whether it is compiled with 1.4.1 or 1.3.1 as summarized here:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;                          Run with:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;                          1.3.1_04        1.4.1_03&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Compiled with:  1.3.1_04    fail            pass &lt;/p&gt;

            <summary>[collections] TestObservedBag and TestObservedSet fail under Java 1.3.1</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12405085" author="janekdb@yahoo.co.uk" created="Sat, 20 Sep 2003 03:37:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I looked into this a (tiny) bit and discovered that the fault is related to an&lt;br/&gt;
assumption made in ObservedTestHelper.doTestRemoveIterated(ObservedFactory&lt;br/&gt;
factory) about the order of elements returned by the iterator:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        coll.addAll(SIX_SEVEN_LIST);&lt;br/&gt;
        LISTENER.preEvent = null;&lt;br/&gt;
        LISTENER.postEvent = null;&lt;br/&gt;
        Assert.assertEquals(2, coll.size());&lt;br/&gt;
        Iterator it = coll.iterator();&lt;br/&gt;
        it.next();&lt;br/&gt;
        it.next();&lt;br/&gt;
        it.remove();&lt;br/&gt;
        Assert.assertEquals(1, coll.size());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here the last element of the collection is removed however the order the&lt;br/&gt;
elements returned by the iterator is different between JDK 1.3.1 and JDK 1.4.1.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The order by type is show here:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;                       1.3.1    1.4.1     &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  ObservedBag          7, 6     6, 7&lt;br/&gt;
  ObservedBuffer       6, 7     6, 7&lt;br/&gt;
  ObservedCollection   6, 7     6, 7&lt;br/&gt;
  ObservedList         6, 7     6, 7&lt;br/&gt;
  ObservedSet          7, 6     6, 7&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405086" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 20 Sep 2003 19:17:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed, good catch, thanks&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-18] [collections] ListOrderedSet broken or documentation wrong.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-18</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The method ListOrderedSet.decorate(List list) &quot;decorates&quot; the list, implying &lt;br/&gt;
that it leaves the underlying list un-modified.  But this is just not true - it &lt;br/&gt;
requires a modifiable List so it can remove duplicates.  It should at least &lt;br/&gt;
warn about this - so you don&apos;t have to look in the code to see how it works and &lt;br/&gt;
see why it fails when using an unmodifiable list (such as given by &lt;br/&gt;
java.util.Collections.unmodifiableList()).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Actually it&apos;d be good to have a variant that worked with unmodifiable lists.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341853">COLLECTIONS-18</key>
            <summary>[collections] ListOrderedSet broken or documentation wrong.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="rlenard">Rohan Lenard</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 5 Nov 2004 08:45:30 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:57 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:57 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.1</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12407957" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Tue, 4 Jan 2005 09:02:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The class is behaving as intended,, although I can see why you might have been&lt;br/&gt;
confused. I have added extra javadoc.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">
                        <customfieldname>Attachment count</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>0.0</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        <customfield id="customfield_10010" key="com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:importid">
                        <customfieldname>Bugzilla Id</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>32073</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310220" key="com.atlassian.jira.ext.charting:firstresponsedate">
                        <customfieldname>Date of First Response</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>Tue, 4 Jan 2005 09:02:21 +0000</customfieldvalue>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310420" key="com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank">
                        <customfieldname>Global Rank</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>18980</customfieldvalue>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-16] ExtendedProperties never sets isInitialized</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-16</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;ExtendedProperties.isInitialized() is always false.  The only code that sets it&lt;br/&gt;
is in a private init() function that is never called.  Some other apps (Torque)&lt;br/&gt;
have depended on isInitialized being set to true after a load but apparently the&lt;br/&gt;
Torque devs never realized it wasn&apos;t.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ll attach a patch to correct this.  The patch removes the private, never used,&lt;br/&gt;
init() function and sets isInitialized on either a load() or addProperty().&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340496">COLLECTIONS-16</key>
            <summary>ExtendedProperties never sets isInitialized</summary>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-15] [collection] ListOrderedSet doesn&apos;t implements SortedSet</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-15</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Is it a good reason why ListOrderedSet implements Set but not SortedSet?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341483">COLLECTIONS-15</key>
            <summary>[collection] ListOrderedSet doesn&apos;t implements SortedSet</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mguillemot@yahoo.fr">Marc Guillemot</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 3 Jun 2004 17:43:29 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:57 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:57 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12406722" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Fri, 4 Jun 2004 04:28:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yes. Because a SortedSet must be sorted (A-Z or Z-A or 1-100 or some other &lt;br/&gt;
sorting order). The iterator returns this sorted order no matter what order the &lt;br/&gt;
elements are added in.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ListOrderedSet simply maintains the order in which the elements are added to &lt;br/&gt;
the set. The iterator always returns the order of adding the elements.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406723" author="mguillemot@yahoo.fr" created="Fri, 4 Jun 2004 14:36:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t fully agree.&lt;br/&gt;
From the javadoc for a SortedSet:&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;sorted according to the natural ordering of its elements (see Comparable), or&lt;br/&gt;
by a Comparator provided at sorted set creation time.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A &quot;UnmodifiableListOrderedSet&quot; would obey this rule as the &quot;comparator&quot; would be&lt;br/&gt;
provided at creation time through the list. It is discutable as soon as more&lt;br/&gt;
than 1 element can be added to the set as the &quot;comparator&quot; would not only need&lt;br/&gt;
the information provided at creation time but should know about the previous&lt;br/&gt;
additions.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406724" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 5 Jun 2004 05:29:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;ListOrderedSet does not currently hold a Comparator as an instance variable, &lt;br/&gt;
nor should it. This class aims to solve the problem of keeping the Set in the &lt;br/&gt;
same order as elements are added.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Looking at the SortedSet interface, the comparator() method is irrelevant, first&lt;br/&gt;
() and last() could be supported. The set views head/tail/sub all rely on a &lt;br/&gt;
comparator based ordering.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">

                            <customfieldvalue>0.0</customfieldvalue>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-14] [collections] Missing putAll(Map map) in MultiHashMap since 3.1</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-14</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I just upgraded to version 3.1 and noticed some errors in my application. The &lt;br/&gt;
cause is the method putAll(Map map) I used to call on a MultiHashMap to copy to &lt;br/&gt;
content of one to another. That method is not defined in MultiHashMap any more, &lt;br/&gt;
so HashMap.putAll(Map map) is used. The result of that is a MultiHashMap that &lt;br/&gt;
contains ONE value per key and the value itself is a Collection.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here is some test code I would expect to work, but it fails:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public class MultiHashMapTest extends TestCase&lt;br/&gt;
{&lt;br/&gt;
    public void testIt()&lt;/p&gt;
    {
        MultiMap original = new MultiHashMap();
        original.put(&quot;key&quot;, &quot;object1&quot;);
        original.put(&quot;key&quot;, &quot;object2&quot;);

        MultiMap copy = new MultiHashMap();
        copy.putAll(original);

        assertEquals(original.values().size(), copy.values().size());
        assertTrue(copy.containsValue(&quot;object1&quot;));
        assertTrue(copy.containsValue(&quot;object2&quot;));
    }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows 2000&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342356">COLLECTIONS-14</key>
            <summary>[collections] Missing putAll(Map map) in MultiHashMap since 3.1</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sven.macke@rewe.de">Sven Macke</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 6 Jul 2005 23:44:56 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:57 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:57 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.1</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12409739" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Fri, 8 Jul 2005 09:04:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This method was removed in November 2002 as it didn&apos;t do anything:&lt;br/&gt;
    public void putAll(Map mapToPut) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        super.putAll(mapToPut);
    }
&lt;p&gt;so, the removal of the method is not the problem.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The problem is that this test case will never have worked.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12409740" author="sven.macke@rewe.de" created="Fri, 8 Jul 2005 16:50:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The test code worked for 2.1 so I had a closer look at the sources. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You are right, the problem ist NOT the missing method HashMap.putAll(Map map) &lt;br/&gt;
but differences in the implementation of HashMap.put(Object key, Object value). &lt;br/&gt;
In 2.1 there is a check whether &quot;value&quot; is an ArrayList (-&amp;gt; call super.put(key, &lt;br/&gt;
value)) or not (-&amp;gt; add value to the interal ArrayList for that key).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12409741" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 17 Jul 2005 03:10:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The put(Object,Object) where value=ArrayList functionality was removed a very&lt;br/&gt;
long time ago, what is now svn rv130874 (24th November 2002).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The implementation that was there at that time was broken (it didn&apos;t merge&lt;br/&gt;
entries, it wiped them), and it was against the Map contract in various ways.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is also not specified by the MultiMap interface.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, what I committed to SVN rv209683 will fix the original bug report,&lt;br/&gt;
whereby you couldn&apos;t clone a multmap using putAll.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">
                        <customfieldname>Attachment count</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>0.0</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        <customfield id="customfield_10010" key="com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:importid">
                        <customfieldname>Bugzilla Id</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>35631</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310220" key="com.atlassian.jira.ext.charting:firstresponsedate">
                        <customfieldname>Date of First Response</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>Fri, 8 Jul 2005 09:04:48 +0000</customfieldvalue>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310420" key="com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank">
                        <customfieldname>Global Rank</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>18984</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>

                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>0|i0sjuv:</customfieldvalue>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-13] [collections] Typo in user documentation</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-13</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Will attach patch momentarily.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342003">COLLECTIONS-13</key>
            <summary>[collections] Typo in user documentation</summary>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-12] ListOrderedSet add results in separate objects in set/list if equal</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-12</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If you add an object to ListOrderedSet, and then try to replace the object with&lt;br/&gt;
add and the objects are different but equals() is true, you will have two&lt;br/&gt;
different objects in the internal list and set so after you do an add, doing a&lt;br/&gt;
listorderedset.get&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/information.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; will return the old object.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342673">COLLECTIONS-12</key>
            <summary>ListOrderedSet add results in separate objects in set/list if equal</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-11] [Collections] LazyList throws IndexOutOfBoundsException when trying to set a value out of list bounds</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-11</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This was discovered when using struts 1.2.7 with dynamic forms (Tomcat 5.0.24,&lt;br/&gt;
jdk 1.4.2). The reset() method in the ActionForm used LazyList.decorate(). &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        if(rooms==null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            rooms = new ArrayList();
            roomPrefs.add(&quot;-&quot;);
            roomPrefs = LazyList.decorate(roomPrefs, factory);
        }


&lt;p&gt;However after reset() I get the error below when it tries to initialize the&lt;br/&gt;
ArrayList. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;IndexOutOfBoundsException -&amp;gt; Index: 1, Size: 1&lt;br/&gt;
java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException: Index: 1, Size: 1&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.util.ArrayList.RangeCheck(ArrayList.java:507)&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.util.ArrayList.set(ArrayList.java:340)&lt;br/&gt;
	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.list.AbstractListDecorator.set(AbstractListDecorator.java:97)&lt;br/&gt;
	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.beanutils.PropertyUtilsBean.setIndexedProperty(PropertyUtilsBean.java:1417)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.beanutils.BeanUtilsBean.setProperty(BeanUtilsBean.java:1016)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.beanutils.BeanUtilsBean.populate(BeanUtilsBean.java:811)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.beanutils.BeanUtils.populate(BeanUtils.java:298)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.struts.util.RequestUtils.populate(RequestUtils.java:493)&lt;br/&gt;
	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.struts.action.RequestProcessor.processPopulate(RequestProcessor.java:805)&lt;br/&gt;
	at ....&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Possible Solution: For now I&apos;ve created a class similar to LazyList and have&lt;br/&gt;
overridden the set(object, element) method and it has worked. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public Object set(int index, Object element) {&lt;br/&gt;
        int size = list.size();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        // Grow the list&lt;br/&gt;
        if (index &amp;gt;= size) {&lt;br/&gt;
            for (int i = size; i &amp;lt;= index; i++) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                list.add(null);
            }
&lt;p&gt;        }&lt;br/&gt;
        return list.set(index, element);&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m not sure if I&apos;m using LazyList the right way but thought I&apos;d bring it to&lt;br/&gt;
your attention.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks!&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342709">COLLECTIONS-11</key>
            <summary>[Collections] LazyList throws IndexOutOfBoundsException when trying to set a value out of list bounds</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="5">Cannot Reproduce</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="hestonfernandes@yahoo.com">Heston Fernandes</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 11 Nov 2005 01:05:07 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:57 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:57 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.1</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12410867" author="hestonfernandes@yahoo.com" created="Fri, 11 Nov 2005 01:10:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The correct code that failed was&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;       if(roomPrefs==null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            roomPrefs = new ArrayList();
            roomPrefs.add(&quot;-&quot;);
            roomPrefs = LazyList.decorate(roomPrefs, factory);
        }</comment>
                            <comment id="12410868" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Fri, 11 Nov 2005 09:12:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;LazyList is performing as expected. It only expands the list when get(index) is&lt;br/&gt;
called.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The class that you want is GrowthList, which expands the list on add() and&lt;br/&gt;
set(). (You can decorate with both GrowthList and LazyList together!)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, GrowthList is unreleased at present, so you will need a nightly build,&lt;br/&gt;
or to checkout SVN and build your own jar.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

            <summary>[collections] ~20 Javadoc fixes and type cast  clean ups.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-7] [collections] BlockingBuffer waits/notifies wrong Object?</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-7</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The code contains various examples of the form:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;synchronized (lock) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            ...
            notifyAll();
        }

&lt;p&gt;which should probably be:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;synchronized (lock) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            ...
            lock.notifyAll();
        }

&lt;p&gt;Patch to follow&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342621">COLLECTIONS-7</key>
            <summary>[collections] BlockingBuffer waits/notifies wrong Object?</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb@apache.org">Sebb</reporter>

                            <comment id="12410596" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 12 Oct 2005 04:23:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=16663)&lt;br/&gt;
Patch to fix wait/notify to use lock Object&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410597" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Wed, 12 Oct 2005 06:11:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This seemed terrible when I first read it, however it turns out that the fix&lt;br/&gt;
(while needed) is in effect a NOP.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For all cases, the lock object and this are the same object, ie. this. Hence,&lt;br/&gt;
the current code (and decent test case) passes.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Amyway, thanks for the spot. The truly correct code is now committed for code&lt;br/&gt;
reading clarity.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

&lt;p&gt;The code is now safer - someone might decide to change lock to be a different &lt;br/&gt;
Object at some point.&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-6] [Collections] - MapUtils]Method to generate a Map from a Object[][]</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-6</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In Python Language it is possible create a dictionary (equivalent to Map) using &lt;br/&gt;
only a single line:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;myMap = &lt;/p&gt;
{&apos;alpha&apos;:&apos;a&apos;, &apos;betha&apos;:&apos;b&apos;, &apos;gamma&apos;:&apos;c&apos;}

&lt;p&gt;In Java it is not possible. We must do it &quot;manually&quot;:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Map myMap = new HashMap();&lt;br/&gt;
myMap.put(&quot;alpha&quot;, &quot;a&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
myMap.put(&quot;betha&quot;, &quot;b&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
myMap.put(&quot;gamma&quot;, &quot;c&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;My propose is create a way to do this with less burocracy. In &lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.MapUtils class could have a method called &lt;br/&gt;
fillMap (or better name) that receives a Map and a bi-dimentional array of &lt;br/&gt;
Objects. It will work like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public static Map fillMap(Map map, Object[][] keyValue) {&lt;br/&gt;
	for(int i = 0; i &amp;lt; keyValue.length; i ++) &lt;/p&gt;
{
		map.put(keyValue[i][0], keyValue[i][1]);
	}
&lt;p&gt;	return map;&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So, returning to prior example, we could do this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Map myMap = MapUtils.fillMap(new HashMap(), {{&quot;alpha&quot;, &quot;a&quot;}, &lt;/p&gt;
{&quot;betha&quot;, &quot;b&quot;}
&lt;p&gt;, &lt;br/&gt;
{&quot;gama&quot;, &quot;c&quot;}});&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Or to put in mass in a pre-existent MAP:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;MapUtils.fillMap(myMap, {{&quot;delta&quot;, &quot;d&quot;}, &lt;/p&gt;
{&quot;epslon&quot;, &quot;e&quot;}
&lt;p&gt;, {&quot;omega&quot;, &quot;z&quot;}});&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341663">COLLECTIONS-6</key>
            <summary>[Collections] - MapUtils]Method to generate a Map from a Object[][]</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>

Class with proposed method fillMap(Map, Object[][])&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-5] [collections] Map.debug/verbosePrint Thread Safety</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-5</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This bug records a discussion on the mailing list, and provides a forum for &lt;br/&gt;
continuing that discussion.  I include below the content of the mailing on the &lt;br/&gt;
list because they raise some interesting points.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;-----------------------------------------------------&lt;br/&gt;
From: &quot;Arun Thomas&quot; &amp;lt;Arun.Thomas@solidusnetworks.com&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
-----------------------------------------------------&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I recently noticed that the current implementation of the debugPrint and &lt;br/&gt;
verbosePrint methods in MapUtils is not thread safe - in fact, these are the &lt;br/&gt;
only items that are not thread safe because the indentation state for the &lt;br/&gt;
output is preserved in a static variable. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think it would be fairly simple to make this thread safe, but it would &lt;br/&gt;
require a change to the signature of a protected member function printIndent&lt;br/&gt;
(PrintStream out) -&amp;gt; printIndent(PrintStream out, int indentDepth).  I&apos;m not &lt;br/&gt;
really clear as to why this method is protected rather than private (can &lt;br/&gt;
anyone clarify?).  Does it need to be protected? &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Looking forward to input from others.&lt;br/&gt;
-AMT &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;------------------------------------------------------&lt;br/&gt;
From: Stephen Colebourne &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;scolebourne@btopenworld.com&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
------------------------------------------------------&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The methods that call this one are synchronized to protect them, so it&lt;br/&gt;
should be thread-safe.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, I would prefer them not to need to be synchronized. If you want to&lt;br/&gt;
submit a patch that reworks the methods that would be great.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Incompatable change?&lt;br/&gt;
The protected method should remain and be deprecated, as it may be used by a&lt;br/&gt;
MapUtils subclass (feasible but unlikely). However, I would prefer just to&lt;br/&gt;
go incompatable change on this one. Other committers may differ, but if they&lt;br/&gt;
don&apos;t I&apos;ll just commit the incompatable change.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Stephen&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;---------------------------------------&lt;br/&gt;
From: Janek Bogucki &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;yan@studylink.com&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
---------------------------------------&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;These methods are synchronized so are currently thread safe.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public static synchronized void verbosePrint (...)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public static synchronized void debugPrint (...)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I would guess that a second intentional benefit of the synchronization&lt;br/&gt;
is to prevent overlapping invocations writing to System.out at the same&lt;br/&gt;
time.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;-Janek&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;------------------------------------------------------&lt;br/&gt;
From: Stephen Colebourne &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;scolebourne@btopenworld.com&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
------------------------------------------------------&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I like the System.out theory. Its probably unintentional, but it true. So&lt;br/&gt;
only a documentation patch is required then...&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Stephen&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340959">COLLECTIONS-5</key>
            <summary>[collections] Map.debug/verbosePrint Thread Safety</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="amamment">Arun Mammen Thomas</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 11 Sep 2003 10:26:43 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:57 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:57 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12405038" author="amamment" created="Thu, 11 Sep 2003 10:36:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;First of all, after Stephen&apos;s original comment, I created a patch and came &lt;br/&gt;
back online in order to create this bug and attach the patch.  I will do so &lt;br/&gt;
anyway, though whether or not this is the appropriate patch has yet to be &lt;br/&gt;
determined.  The patch makes use of the fact that debugPrint and verbosePrint &lt;br/&gt;
both delegate to verbosePrintInternal to pass on an extra variable &lt;br/&gt;
(indentDepth) removing the need for that state to be represented as part of &lt;br/&gt;
the class state.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The old printIndent method has been deprecated, though, as you will see from &lt;br/&gt;
the comments I include in the patch, it doesn&apos;t make much sense to do so.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;That said, I&apos;d like to address here Janek&apos;s comment about preventing &lt;br/&gt;
overlapping invokations from writing to System.out at the same time.  I can &lt;br/&gt;
see why that would be useful, but I think forcing the synchronization on the &lt;br/&gt;
class (particularly a utility class like this) is the worst way to do it.  &lt;br/&gt;
This will prevent, as Janek notes, overlapping invokations to debugPrint and &lt;br/&gt;
verbosePrint from interfering with each other.  However....&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) There is no lock on System.out.  In a multi-threaded environment, other &lt;br/&gt;
sources of output outside this class may well be writing to System.out at the &lt;br/&gt;
same time.  Such output may be interlaced with output from these two &lt;br/&gt;
synchronized methods - there is no guard against such behavior.  As a result, &lt;br/&gt;
preventing interlacing of output will most likely require an external guard &lt;br/&gt;
anyway.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2) The cost of synchronizing these two methods is that none of the otherwise &lt;br/&gt;
thread safe methods in this utility class can be used while any thread is &lt;br/&gt;
using either debugPrint or verbosePrint.  Any thread desiring to use any of &lt;br/&gt;
the other utilities will be blocked until all output is written.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;IMHO, the two reasons above both suggest that the synchronized keyword should &lt;br/&gt;
be removed - any synchronization should be external - perhaps with the &lt;br/&gt;
additional class level documentation that the methods themselves are thread-&lt;br/&gt;
safe and do not require explicit synchronization.  &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405039" author="amamment" created="Thu, 11 Sep 2003 10:37:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=8144)&lt;br/&gt;
Update to make debugPrint and verbosePrint thread safe&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405040" author="amamment" created="Thu, 11 Sep 2003 10:38:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Note that the patch attached just previouslyt does not, in fact, remove the &lt;br/&gt;
synchronized keyword from debugPrint and verbosePrint.  I think it should be &lt;br/&gt;
removed, but I realized I had forgotten to do it.  I can submit another patch &lt;br/&gt;
with those removed if required.  &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405041" author="janekdb@yahoo.co.uk" created="Thu, 11 Sep 2003 14:50:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I agree with Arun&apos;s removal of the synchronized key on these two methods. As &lt;br/&gt;
he correctly points out it will not, in general, prevent overlapping use of &lt;br/&gt;
System.out.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405042" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 20 Sep 2003 18:33:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Changes made so synchronization is now the responsibility of the caller if &lt;br/&gt;
required.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;(I should note that one thread in a synchronized method does NOT block access &lt;br/&gt;
to non synchronized methods from another thread)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                            <attachment id="12332517" name="ASF.LICENSE.NOT.GRANTED--patch.txt" size="4195" author="amamment" created="Thu, 11 Sep 2003 10:37:14 +0000"/>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-4] Calling CollectionUtils.cardinality with null obj argument leads to NPE</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-4</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;There is a bug in cardinality method, which shows, when obj parameter is null;&lt;br/&gt;
It leads to NullPointerException.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In order to reveal it, add line&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;assertEquals(0, CollectionUtils.cardinality(null, _b));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;to testCardinality in TestCollectionUtils.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;One variant of correct implementation is following:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public static int cardinality(Object obj, final Collection col) {&lt;br/&gt;
       int count = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
       Iterator it = col.iterator();&lt;br/&gt;
       if(null==obj){&lt;br/&gt;
           while(it.hasNext()){&lt;br/&gt;
               Object elt = it.next();&lt;br/&gt;
               if(null==elt)&lt;/p&gt;
{
                   count++;
               }&lt;br/&gt;
           }&lt;br/&gt;
       }else{&lt;br/&gt;
           while(it.hasNext()) {&lt;br/&gt;
               Object elt = it.next();&lt;br/&gt;
               if(obj.equals(elt)) {                   count++;               }
&lt;p&gt;           }&lt;br/&gt;
       }&lt;br/&gt;
       return count;&lt;br/&gt;
   }&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340376">COLLECTIONS-4</key>
            <summary>Calling CollectionUtils.cardinality with null obj argument leads to NPE</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-3] NPE: map.LRUMap.reuseMapping(LRUMap.java:272)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-3</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m using Collections 3.1 and just found this NPE in my logs:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.lang.NullPointerException&lt;br/&gt;
        at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.map.LRUMap.reuseMapping(LRUMap.java:272)&lt;br/&gt;
        at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.map.LRUMap.addMapping(LRUMap.java:243)&lt;br/&gt;
        at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.collections.map.AbstractHashedMap.put(AbstractHashedMap.java:282)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I instantiated LRUMap like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  LRUMap map = new LRUMap(31);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And from there on, I use it like I&apos;d use any Map, putting things into&lt;br/&gt;
it, and so on.  Maybe I&apos;m not using LRUMap correctly?  My &lt;em&gt;guess&lt;/em&gt; is&lt;br/&gt;
that this occurs when the Map is full, but I am not certain.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I am wrapping the LRUMap in my own Maps as follows, but I think they&apos;re&lt;br/&gt;
not the culprit:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  LRUMap map = new LRUMap(31);&lt;br/&gt;
    _userSessions = new ExpiringMap(map,&lt;br/&gt;
       new TimerTTLReferenceHolder(1800000), // ttl=30min&lt;br/&gt;
       300000);                              // purge frequency=5min&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;The only similar thing I found is &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-141&quot; title=&quot;add flag to LRUMap to allow scan of next removeable entry&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;COLLECTIONS-141&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;COM-1288&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;, but it looks like that was fixed&lt;br/&gt;
before 3.1 release.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I understand the value of a self-contained unit test that demonstrates this bug,&lt;br/&gt;
but it happens only occassionally on my production system, never during&lt;br/&gt;
development, so I can&apos;t really come up with it &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/sad.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;My guess is that this is a boundary case, as line 272 is:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; loop = loop.next;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So &apos;loop&apos; is most likely null, and it&apos;s null because ... not sure, maybe that&lt;br/&gt;
hashIndex is wrong.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Linux&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341922">COLLECTIONS-3</key>
            <summary>NPE: map.LRUMap.reuseMapping(LRUMap.java:272)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="5">Cannot Reproduce</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="otis@apache.org">Otis Gospodnetic</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 8 Dec 2004 03:39:44 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 28 Feb 2013 19:53:32 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 17 Jun 2009 09:48:47 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.1</version>

                        <due></due>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12408255" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Fri, 4 Feb 2005 09:28:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Just a thought, but could your keys be changing after you insert them into the&lt;br/&gt;
map? Hash keys need to be immutable (or not changed) after being added as a key&lt;br/&gt;
in a map.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408256" author="kreiger" created="Wed, 2 Mar 2005 01:11:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have a customer reporting the same problem, and i&apos;m using java.lang.Integer&lt;br/&gt;
for the keys, and java.lang.ref.SoftReference for the values.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408257" author="kreiger" created="Wed, 2 Mar 2005 01:20:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sorry, wrong. I&apos;m using array of SoftReference (SoftReference[]) for the values.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408258" author="endo@sb.net" created="Sun, 20 Mar 2005 04:13:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hello I am reporting a similar problem which makes LRUMap useless.  I am using &lt;br/&gt;
LRUMap as a synchronizedMap.  I can confirm that this problem only occurs when &lt;br/&gt;
the LRUMap becomes full, but not right away.  The problem may or may not arise &lt;br/&gt;
(there is no pattern).  I am using LRUMap in a web environment to cache some &lt;br/&gt;
stuff - the cache size is 40000.  Once the problem starts the problem &lt;br/&gt;
continues with each next put.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.lang.NullPointerException &lt;br/&gt;
org/apache/commons/collections/map/LRUMap.addMapping&lt;br/&gt;
(IILjava/lang/Object;Ljava/lang/Object;)V+0 (LRUMap.java:227) &lt;br/&gt;
org/apache/commons/collections/map/AbstractHashedMap.put&lt;br/&gt;
(Ljava/lang/Object;Ljava/lang/Object;)Ljava/lang/Object;+0 &lt;br/&gt;
(AbstractHashedMap.java:269) &lt;br/&gt;
java/util/Collections$SynchronizedMap.put(Ljava/lang/Object;Ljava/lang/Object&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Ljava/lang/Object;+11 (Collections.java:1432) &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408259" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Tue, 22 Mar 2005 09:54:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I can reproduce this by not synchronizing access to the LRUMap.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thus there are now two possible causes of this:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Mutable keys (map keys must not be changed)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Not correctly synchronized (use Collections.synchronizedMap)&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Please check your code to ensure that you are using the collections correctly.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408260" author="michael_girard@msn.com" created="Sat, 2 Apr 2005 03:05:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;we are also seeing this issue when using Strings as keys into the LRUMap. We are&lt;br/&gt;

                            <comment id="12408266" author="mliberato@gmail.com" created="Sun, 9 Oct 2005 06:05:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;That really seems a synchronization issue on the client. I have done some tests&lt;br/&gt;
here and the problem only occurs when there are non-thread-safe access to the&lt;br/&gt;
map. Are there more references to this kind of error?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408267" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 9 Oct 2005 06:45:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;(In reply to comment #12)&lt;br/&gt;

&amp;gt; map. Are there more references to this kind of error?&lt;/p&gt;

other (similarly designed) classes have no issues raised.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408268" author="otis@apache.org" created="Sun, 9 Oct 2005 12:37:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m no longer using this LRUMap in the application where I was having problems&lt;br/&gt;
