                            <comment id="12408273" author="jhecking@netgaroo.com" created="Tue, 22 Nov 2005 00:25:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sorry, didn&apos;t mean to close the bug!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Re. comment #17 - we&apos;re running into the same problem when using LRUMap without&lt;br/&gt;
Collections.synchronizedMap(). Here&apos;s the requested info about JRE and OS version:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;$ java -version&lt;br/&gt;
java version &quot;1.4.2_07&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.2_07-b05)&lt;br/&gt;
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.2_07-b05, mixed mode)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;$ uname -a&lt;br/&gt;
Linux XXX 2.6.9-5.ELsmp #1 SMP Wed Jan 5 19:30:39 EST 2005 i686 i686 i386 GNU/Linux&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The NPE occurs when calling LRUMap.put(). The key is immutable (String). We&apos;re&lt;br/&gt;
only using the put() and get() methods.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408274" author="rdonkin@apache.org" created="Tue, 22 Nov 2005 03:05:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi Jan&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the information.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Are you really running without synchronisation?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Is there any chance that mutliple threads are accessing the map?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Robert&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408275" author="jhecking@netgaroo.com" created="Tue, 22 Nov 2005 03:29:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;(In reply to comment #20)&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; Are you really running without synchronisation?&lt;br/&gt;
Yes, before we hit this bug we were running without synchronization. Now we&lt;br/&gt;
wrapped the LRUMap in a Collections.synchronizedMap().&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;gt; Is there any chance that mutliple threads are accessing the map?&lt;br/&gt;
Yes, multiple threads are reading and writing the map.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Off course in this case it was stupid to not use synchronized access in the&lt;br/&gt;
first place as LRUMap does not explicitly state that it is threadsafe...&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408276" author="rdonkin@apache.org" created="Tue, 22 Nov 2005 04:57:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the information. I expect occasional null pointers when this map is&lt;br/&gt;
used by multiple threads without synchronization. I&apos;ll take a look at fixing the&lt;br/&gt;
javadocs. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Have you had any problems since switching to use the synchronized version?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Robert&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408277" author="eric@pandora.com" created="Thu, 13 Apr 2006 06:36:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m currently experiencing an identical problem to what Jan has already reported.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;gt; uname -a&lt;br/&gt;
Linux &amp;lt;snip&amp;gt; 2.6.13.1-20050914 #2 SMP Wed Sep 14 13:54:47 PDT 2005 i686 GNU/Linux&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;gt; vmjava -version&lt;br/&gt;
java version &quot;1.4.1_07&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.1_07-b02)&lt;br/&gt;
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.1_07-b02, mixed mode)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m running Jakarta Commons Collections 3.1.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Like Jan, the NPE occurs when calling LRUMap.put(). The key is immutable&lt;br/&gt;
(String), and we&apos;re only using the put() and get() methods. The offending LRUMap&lt;br/&gt;
is contructed using the LRUMap(int) constructor.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Once the NPE exception within LRUMap.put occurs, all subsequent calls to that&lt;br/&gt;
method also provoke a NPE.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We &lt;b&gt;are&lt;/b&gt; decorating our LRUMap using Collections.synchronizedMap, and the&lt;br/&gt;
problem still occurs.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408278" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Thu, 13 Apr 2006 08:17:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;(In reply to comment #23)&lt;br/&gt;
Are you able to use the debug jar file from comment #10 ?&lt;br/&gt;
It would be great if you could.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also, can you confirm that all iterator access to the map is wrapped as follows:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;synchronized {&lt;br/&gt;
  Iterator it = map.keySet().iterator();&lt;br/&gt;
  while (it.hasNext()) &lt;/p&gt;
{
    ...
  }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ie. that there is a synchronized block around the whole of any iteration?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12509351" author="bayard" created="Sun, 1 Jul 2007 02:54:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;That should be:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;synchronized(map) {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Playing with SoakLRUMap, not doing that gives a ConcurrentModificationException, which hasn&apos;t been reported so far. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Mostly I get IllegalStateExceptions when playing with SoakLRUMap and not synchronizing the Map, however I did get one NPE still:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.lang.NullPointerException&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.collections.map.LRUMap.moveToMRU(LRUMap.java:194)&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.collections.map.LRUMap.updateEntry(LRUMap.java:217)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Line is:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;            entry.before.after = entry.after;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Which, looking at the code, implies that entry.before is null. Maybe another place to put a state check?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Maybe a state check would be worth it there too?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12580252" author="bayard" created="Wed, 19 Mar 2008 06:50:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;TODO: Add the two state checks. Close as Cannot Reproduce.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12584415" author="bayard" created="Wed, 2 Apr 2008 06:04:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Adding a state check as per &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-3&quot; title=&quot;NPE: map.LRUMap.reuseMapping(LRUMap.java:272)&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;COLLECTIONS-3&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;COLLECTIONS-3&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;. I got an NPE when running through tests without synchronization&quot; src&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/collections/map/LRUMap.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data .&lt;br/&gt;
Committed revision 643755.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12584416" author="bayard" created="Wed, 2 Apr 2008 06:05:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Everything points to this being synchronization issues.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12720583" author="joehni" created="Wed, 17 Jun 2009 09:29:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Reopened, added a unit test (currently not executed, marked with TODO) that reproduces the ConcurrentModificationException. Happens only if the remove is called on the iterator from the keySet. Works fine for the iterators from the entrySet and values. See improved unit test TestLRUMap.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12720590" author="joehni" created="Wed, 17 Jun 2009 09:48:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Closed again as &quot;Cannot reproduce&quot;. I will open a new issue for the ConcurrentModificationException. This issue&apos;s history with different reported problems is simply too vague.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[COLLECTIONS-2] [collections] ExtendedProperties.save(...) does not escape special characters</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-2</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If some value ends with &apos;\&apos;, then after saving it, load will fail or will have &lt;br/&gt;
incorrect values.&lt;br/&gt;
Try to store some property with value ending with &apos;\&apos;, eg.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;path1=e:\&lt;br/&gt;
path2=c:\docs&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Look for java.util.Properties on escaping characters.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340665">COLLECTIONS-2</key>
            <summary>[collections] ExtendedProperties.save(...) does not escape special characters</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="dwojtas@myrealbox.com">Dariusz Wojtas</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 16 Apr 2003 18:28:24 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:56 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 21:35:56 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.1</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12404105" author="mohankishore@yahoo.com" created="Sat, 19 Apr 2003 03:42:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=5896)&lt;br/&gt;
Patch for escaping back-slash characters&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404106" author="mohankishore@yahoo.com" created="Sat, 19 Apr 2003 03:48:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Have added a patch for escaping the back-slash characters. When adding a &lt;br/&gt;
Property, now it unescapes the value (i.e. replaces 2 successive back-slashes &lt;br/&gt;
with 1). When saving the object to a file, it escapes the commas and back-&lt;br/&gt;
slashes by placing a back-slash before them.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Have also added test cases for the same.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Note, the patch might break backward compatibility, but the change required to &lt;br/&gt;
the property files would be minimal - i.e. replace all backslashes in the &lt;br/&gt;
values, with 2 backslashes. You (still) need a single backslash at the end of &lt;br/&gt;
the line, in order to continue the value on the next line.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404107" author="rwaldhoff@apache.org" created="Sat, 19 Apr 2003 06:22:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;d be happy to apply this patch, but I&apos;m not really a user of&lt;br/&gt;
ExtendedProperties.  Anyone have any objections?  Going once, going twice...&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404108" author="kevin@henrikson.com" created="Sun, 20 Apr 2003 00:46:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Wouldn&apos;t it be much safer to document the current behavior, and add escaping&lt;br/&gt;
methods for users to use?  This will maintain backward compatibality yet allow&lt;br/&gt;
users that don&apos;t escape their values ahead of time the needed functionality.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404109" author="rwaldhoff@apache.org" created="Sun, 20 Apr 2003 03:01:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If the incompatiablity is troubling, adding something like &quot;escapeAndSave()&quot; or&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;saveSafely()&quot; sounds reasonable to me.  One could even deprecate the old save()&lt;br/&gt;
method, eventually remove it, and eventually (after than) reintroduce it as an&lt;br/&gt;
alias for &quot;saveSafely()&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404110" author="mohankishore@yahoo.com" created="Sun, 20 Apr 2003 03:07:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Actually to think about it, the patch submitted should not break a majority of &lt;br/&gt;
existing files. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When loading, it would condense 2 successive back-slashes in the input file &lt;br/&gt;
into 1, but will read in a single back-slash as is.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I would recommend changing the method save() - the other options seem more &lt;br/&gt;
confusing, imho. This would also make the properties file outputted more &lt;br/&gt;
compatible with the java.util.Properties file. Currently, the commas in the &lt;br/&gt;
values are not escaped, i.e. if you save and load a value with an embeded &lt;br/&gt;
comma, it will come back as an array/vector.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404111" author="dwojtas@myrealbox.com" created="Sun, 20 Apr 2003 03:14:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think tha just modifying save() and documenting it is enough.&lt;br/&gt;
If there are 2 methods to store the same contents resulting in different &lt;br/&gt;
output, there must be 2 methods to read it different way. &lt;br/&gt;
That will lead to many problems is some data files are exchanged with other &lt;br/&gt;
apps or even different modules. No one will now with what method it was stored.&lt;br/&gt;
It should be made compatible with java.util.Properties.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404112" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 26 Apr 2003 22:33:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;OK, my view is that the file produced by the save() method must be readable by &lt;br/&gt;
the load() method. As I read the bug report and the code, that is not currently &lt;br/&gt;
the case. So we should fix it. Creating extra save methods is unecessary.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404113" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 24 Aug 2003 17:54:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch applied with minor changes. Thanks&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                            <attachment id="12332234" name="ASF.LICENSE.NOT.GRANTED--Patch.txt" size="8301" author="mohankishore@yahoo.com" created="Sat, 19 Apr 2003 03:42:55 +0000"/>

            <title>[COLLECTIONS-1] [collections] Collections Javadoc warnings with JDK 1.4.2</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-1</link>
                <project id="12310465" key="COLLECTIONS">Commons Collections</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Numerous javadoc warnings when doing &quot;ant dist&quot; target under JDK 1.4.2.  Partial&lt;br/&gt;
patch to follow&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341022">COLLECTIONS-1</key>
            <summary>[collections] Collections Javadoc warnings with JDK 1.4.2</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

                            <comment id="12405236" author="eric@tibco.com" created="Thu, 9 Oct 2003 01:04:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=8495)&lt;br/&gt;
Fix JDK 1.4.2 Javadoc errors for API classes.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405237" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Fri, 10 Oct 2003 04:03:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch applied, thanks.&lt;br/&gt;
I made a few minor changes, so I hope that I didn&apos;t break anything again &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405238" author="eric@tibco.com" created="Fri, 10 Oct 2003 20:47:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for applying (most of) my first patch!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve got two patches to follow.  The first one notes the remaining issues with&lt;br/&gt;
the collection classes themselves, and the second will be for the test classes.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405239" author="eric@tibco.com" created="Fri, 10 Oct 2003 20:48:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=8522)&lt;br/&gt;
Additional Javadoc issues.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405240" author="eric@tibco.com" created="Fri, 10 Oct 2003 20:56:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Comments about previous patch:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) I changed CommonsLinkedList to &quot;public&quot;, if only because it is extended by&lt;br/&gt;
NodeCachingLinkedList which is public. Via protected functions,&lt;br/&gt;
NodeCachingLinkedList references protected functions of it CommonsLinkedList. &lt;br/&gt;
For consistency, either those functions on NodeCachingLinkedList should be&lt;br/&gt;
private, or CommonsLinkedList should be public.  In my ignorance of the details&lt;br/&gt;
and history, I thought more transparency was better, and opted for the &quot;public&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
change.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2) In several files, I added an import, where the import serves only to block&lt;br/&gt;
warnings by javadoc, and is not needed by the code itself.  The alternative&lt;br/&gt;
would be to fully qualify all the references to StandardModificationHandler in&lt;br/&gt;
the comments, but I thought this change more concise.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for considering these additional changes.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405241" author="eric@tibco.com" created="Fri, 10 Oct 2003 21:56:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=8525)&lt;br/&gt;
Javadoc issues with test framework&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405242" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 11 Oct 2003 04:29:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patches applied.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I can&apos;t make CommonsLinkedList public until it has a test case, so I have to &lt;br/&gt;
take the javadoc issues instead.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I prefer the imports to not throw up &apos;unused import&apos; in Eclipse, so I&apos;m leaving &lt;br/&gt;
the StandardModificationHandler in the javadoc even though its long. With the &lt;br/&gt;
iterators I got around this by directly referencing the iterator in code.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
